questions.text: A 56-year-old female was treated for a burn wound in the lower limb 5 years ago. Now she has developed an ulcer in the burn scar as shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Marjolin’s ulcer:

  • Marjolin's ulcer is a type of skin cancer that arises from chronic non-healing wounds, scars, or ulcers, usually after a prolonged period of time (years).
  • It is most commonly associated with burn wounds.
  • The appearance of a chronic ulcer following a burn injury is a classic indication of Marjolin's ulcer.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Venous ulcer:

  • Venous ulcers typically occur due to chronic venous insufficiency.
  • They usually appear around the ankles and lower legs and are characterized by shallow, irregularly shaped ulcers with a red or yellowish base.
  • They are often associated with edema, varicose veins, and skin discoloration.

Option C - Arterial ulcer:

  • Arterial ulcers are a result of inadequate blood supply to the tissue, usually due to underlying arterial disease such as peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
  • These ulcers often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and are characterized by a "punched out" appearance with well-defined edges.
  • The base may appear pale or necrotic.

Option D - Cellulitis:

  • Cellulitis is a bacterial skin infection that typically presents as redness, swelling, warmth, and pain at the affected site.
  • While cellulitis can occur at sites of wounds or breaks in the skin, it does not typically present as a chronic ulcer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. Radiological imaging shows a blind pouch at the level of the pharynx. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pulsion Diverticula

  • Pulsion diverticula in the esophagus due to increased pressure in the esophageal wall, leading to the outpouching of the mucosa through weakened areas. This can cause symptoms like dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation, and bad breath (halitosis). 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Achalasia Cardia: Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus where the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, causing difficulty in food passage and esophageal dilation. Symptoms include dysphagia, regurgitation, and sometimes weight loss. While lobar pneumonia could potentially result from aspiration due to dysphagia, it is not a defining feature of achalasia.

Option C - CA Esophagus (Esophageal Cancer): Esophageal cancer can lead to dysphagia, weight loss, and other symptoms. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not directly related to esophageal cancer. CA Esophagus does not explain these radiological findings.

Option D - GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease): GERD can cause symptoms like dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation. However, lobar pneumonia and consolidation are not typical consequences of GERD. These symptoms might arise due to chronic aspiration of stomach contents, leading to pneumonia, but GERD alone does not explain the presence of lobar pneumonia.

questions.text: ABCD2 scoring includes all the following parameters except?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - History of stroke 

  • The ABCD2 score is based on 5 parameters.
  Age Blood pressure Clinical features Duration of TIA DM
No point <60 years <140/90 mmHg No speech disturbance and no unilateral weakness <10 minutes Absent
1 point ≥60 years ≥140/90 mmHg Speech disturbance present but no unilateral weakness 10-59 minutes Present
2 point - - Unilateral weakness ≥60 minutes -

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a smoker, presented to the OPD with complaints of fatigue. He is known to be anemic and his sister had a history of endometrial cancer. The physician is considering appropriate colorectal cancer screening methods for this patient. Which screening method should be recommended for colorectal malignancy in this patient?

choices.text: Check for occult blood in stool

questions.solution:
Correct option B - Colonoscopy every 10 years:

  • Colonoscopy every 10 years is the recommended screening method for colorectal malignancy, especially in individuals with risk factors such as a family history of colorectal cancer and a personal history of anemia.
  • Colonoscopy allows for direct visualization of the entire colon and rectum, and it can both detect and remove precancerous growths (polyps) during the same procedure.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Barium enema: Barium enema is not a method for colorectal cancer screening.

Option C - Check for occult blood in stool:

  • Occult blood can be an indicator of gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • While fecal occult blood test (FOBT) is a screening method, it is not the most sensitive test and may require repeated testing.

Option D - Flexible sigmoidoscopy yearly:

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy is a screening method that involves examining the lower part of the colon and rectum using a flexible sigmoidoscope.
  • While it can be effective, it only examines a portion of the colon.
  • Colonoscopy provides a more comprehensive examination of the entire colon and is recommended every 10 years for colorectal cancer screening.

questions.text: During a complicated delivery, a mother died. Which of the following is the most common Direct cause of maternal death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hemorrhage

  • Hemorrhage, is the most common Direct cause of maternal death during complicated delivery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Embolism: An embolism refers to the sudden blockage of a blood vessel by a clot (embolus), which can potentially lead to serious complications. Pulmonary embolism, where a blood clot travels to the lungs, is a known cause of maternal mortality. It can occur during pregnancy, childbirth, or the postpartum period. An embolism can obstruct blood flow and lead to respiratory distress, shock, and even death. While embolism can be a cause of maternal death, but is not the most common direct cause.

Option B - Heart Disease: Pre-existing heart disease in a pregnant woman can increase the risk of complications during childbirth. Cardiac events, such as heart failure, myocardial infarction (heart attack), or arrhythmias, can contribute to maternal death. However, but is not the most common direct cause.

Option D - Anemia: Anemia is most common indirect cause of death.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with redness and a Peau d'orange appearance involving more than 2/3 of her breast, without any palpable lump in the breast. On further evaluation, it is found that the skin involvement extends to the chest wall and is suggestive of inflammatory carcinoma. What is the appropriate TNM staging for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - T4d

T Category T Criteria
TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1a Tumor size ≤1 mm
T1b Tumor size >1 mm but ≤5 mm
T1c Tumor size >5 mm but ≤10 mm
T1d Tumor size >10 mm but ≤20 mm
T2 Tumor size >20 mm but ≤50 mm
T3 Tumor size >50mm
T4a Tumor with chest wall invasion
T4b Tumor with macroscopic skin changes including ulceration and/or satellite skin nodules and/or edema
T4c Tumor with criteria of both T4a and T4b
T4d Inflammatory carcinoma

Incorrect options: Options A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presented with RTA and is brought to ER with a pulse rate of 120/min, and SBP of <80mmHg. Despite intravenous fluid resuscitation and BT, the patient's condition deteriorates with ongoing profuse bleeding from the liver. Identify the procedure shown in the image done to control massive liver bleed.
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Pringle's maneuver

  • Pringle's maneuver involves temporarily clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament, which contains the portal vein, hepatic artery, and common bile duct.
  • This maneuver is used to control bleeding from the liver by temporarily interrupting blood flow to the liver.
  • It is a common technique used during liver surgery or to manage traumatic liver bleeding.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Kocher maneuver:

  • Kocher maneuver is a surgical technique used during cholecystectomy to mobilize the duodenum and improve access to the gallbladder.
  • It is not relevant to controlling liver bleeding.

Option C - Cattell-Braasch maneuver:

  • Cattell-Braasch maneuver is a mobilization surgical technique that allows good access to the retroperitoneal structures.
  • The inferior vena cava, abdominal aorta below the superior mesenteric artery, and retroperitoneal organs of the right side are exposed when it is completed.

Option D - Mattox maneuver:

  • Mattox maneuver, also known as a left medial visceral rotation, is a surgical step to explore and handle Zone 1 and 2 retroperitoneal injuries (aorta, left iliac and pelvic vessels).
  • It starts with incising the parietal peritoneum at the white line of Toldt from the sigmoid colon to the splenic flexure.

questions.text: What type of material is in the mesh used in Lichtenstein hernioplasty?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Polypropylene: In Lichtenstein hernioplasty, polypropylene meshes are used to reinforce the abdominal wall and prevent hernia recurrence due to their long-term stability and minimal tissue reaction.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are not used as mesh material in Lichtenstein hernioplasty.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a unique psychological phenomenon in which they believe that a close family member has been replaced by an imposter with an uncanny resemblance. This is commonly seen in which type of dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lewy body dementia:

  • Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in Lewy body dementia.
  • Lewy body dementia is characterized by cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations and parkinsonism symptoms.
  • Capgras syndrome involves a delusion that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect because Capgras syndrome is not associated with option A, C and D

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient had a RTA and was brought to the emergency room with bradycardia and a high BP. The GCS of this patient is < 8. What should be the immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Intubate and IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation):

  • The patient's presentation of bradycardia, high blood pressure and a low GCS score (<8) is indicative of increased intracranial pressure and a potential impending herniation.
  • Intubation and intermittent positive pressure ventilation helps in maintaining adequate oxygenation and ventilation and reducing intracranial pressure.
  • This intervention aims to protect the patient's airway and prevent further deterioration of their condition.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A 35-years-old patient presents with complaints of sudden and irresistible urges to take action. This is the characteristic of which symptom?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Impulse:

  • Impulse is a sudden and irresistible urge to take a specific action.
  • It is a strong and often uncontrollable desire to perform an action without much forethought or consideration of the consequences.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Hallucination: Hallucination refers to perceiving something that is not actually present in the external environment.

Option C - Delusion: Delusion is a fixed, false belief that is resistant to reason or contrary evidence.

Option D - Pseudohallucination: Pseudohallucination is similar to hallucinations but are recognized by the person as being generated by their own mind.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with persistent feelings of sadness, fatigue, loss of appetite and lack of motivation for the past several weeks. On further assessment, the patient reports a decreased interest in activities that were once enjoyable and a general sense of hopelessness. Which of the following is the key symptom of depression?

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Low mood:

  • This is the key symptom of depression. Persistent feelings of sadness, low mood, or emptiness are often the hallmark of depressive episodes. It's not just feeling down occasionally; it's a pervasive and lasting emotional state that significantly impacts a person's overall well-being.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Suicidal ideations: While suicidal ideations can be a serious symptom of depression, they are not the key symptom that defines depression. Many individuals with depression may not experience suicidal thoughts, but they can still exhibit other characteristic symptoms.

Option C- Loss of interest in pleasurable activity: This is indeed a symptom of depression, but it is not the key defining symptom. Anhedonia, or the loss of interest in activities that were once pleasurable, is commonly seen in depression, but it is usually accompanied by other symptoms like low mood and fatigue.

Option D- Loss of Appetite: Changes in appetite, including both overeating and loss of appetite, are common in depression. However, like option C, this is a symptom often seen in conjunction with other symptoms rather than being the key defining symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a layer of esophagus?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Serosa

The esophagus contains 4 layers:

  1. Mucosa
  2. Submucosa
  3. Muscularis
  4. Tunica adventitia

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of abdominal pain, fever and vomiting. On examination, there is a palpable mass in right iliac fossa with leukocytosis. What is the management plan for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Ochsner-Sherren regime:

  • Ochsner-Sherren regime is for the management of acute appendicular mass.
  • It refers to a conservative approach involving antibiotics and bed rest for the treatment of an acute appendicular mass.
  • The strategy of this regime is based on the presumption that the inflammatory process is already localized and that inadvertent surgery is challenging and may be unsafe.
  • However, in many cases, surgical intervention is the preferred treatment.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Alvarado scoring: Alvarado scoring is a clinical scoring system used to assess the likelihood of acute appendicitis.

Option C - Laparoscopic appendectomy: Laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to remove the inflamed appendix.

Option D - Cholecystectomy: Cholecystectomy is the surgical removal of the gallbladder.

questions.text: A patient presented with alopecia of unknown origin and abdominal discomfort. What could be the most likely diagnosis based on the image below, which was retrieved from the stomach following a surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Trichobezoar:

  • Trichobezoar is a mass of hair that forms within the stomach, occurring in individuals with a condition known as trichotillomania.
  • Trichotillomania is a compulsive habit of pulling out their own hair and sometimes ingesting it.
  • The image shows a mass that could potentially be a trichobezoar, which explains the patient's symptoms of abdominal discomfort.
  • The patient also has alopecia of unknown origin, which further suggests a connection to trichotillomania.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension within 2 days of birth. An X-ray abdomen was performed which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Duodenal atresia

  • Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition in which there is a complete or partial obstruction of the lumen of the duodenum.
  • This obstruction can lead to bilious vomiting and abdominal distension shortly after birth.
  • X-ray image shows a characteristic "double bubble" sign, where there are two distinct air-filled bubbles in the abdomen, one representing the stomach and the other the dilated portion of the proximal duodenum, which is a typical radiological finding in duodenal atresia.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Pyloric stenosis:

  • Pyloric stenosis is a condition in which the muscle at the pylorus becomes abnormally thickened, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • It typically presents with projectile, non-bilious vomiting and a palpable "olive-like" mass in the upper abdomen.
  • X-ray findings for pyloric stenosis usually include a "string sign" - a narrow pyloric channel.

Option C - Esophageal atresia:

  • Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition in which the esophagus does not develop properly.
  • This condition is associated with difficulty swallowing, drooling, choking and cyanosis.
  • X-ray shows an absence of air in the stomach and the presence of air in the proximal esophagus.

Option D - Gas in bowel: Gas in the bowel is a common finding in X-ray images of the abdomen and is present in normal conditions as well as various pathological conditions. It does not provide a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient is showing stubbornness, rigidity and frugality. In which stage we can see this kind of behaviour due to fixation according to psychosexual stages of development?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Anal:

  • In Sigmund Freud's psychosexual stages of development, the anal stage occurs typically around ages 1 to 3 years. During this stage, the child's focus of pleasure and development centers on the anal region. The main conflict of this stage is related to toilet training and the child's ability to control their bowel movements. The child learns to gain satisfaction from retaining and expelling feces.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Oral Stage: The oral stage occurs during infancy (birth to around 1 year old). Pleasure centers on the mouth and the activities related to it, such as sucking and feeding. Fixation during this stage might result in behaviors like smoking, overeating, or a dependency on oral stimulation for comfort.

Option C - Phallic Stage: The phallic stage emerges around ages 3 to 6 years. During this stage, children become aware of their own gender and develop feelings of attraction towards the opposite-sex parent and rivalry with the same-sex parent (Oedipus and Electra complexes). Fixation during this stage might lead to challenges in forming healthy relationships and issues related to gender identity and self-esteem.

Option D - Genital Stage: The genital stage occurs from puberty onwards. This stage is characterized by the mature development of sexual interests and the establishment of healthy intimate relationships. Fixation during this stage might lead to difficulties in forming lasting relationships and a lack of fulfillment in adult sexual relationships.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male who had a road traffic accident and suffered from chest trauma was admitted to the ER. About 1800 ml of blood loss from the chest tube in an hour. What is the next step in management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Emergency Thoracotomy:

  • In a case where a 39-year-old male has suffered chest trauma with heavy bleeding in the lungs and significant blood loss (1800 ml) from the chest tube in an hour, an emergency thoracotomy is the appropriate next step. A thoracotomy involves making an incision into the chest wall to access the thoracic cavity. This procedure allows direct control of bleeding, repair of injuries, and potential life-saving measures. Given the severity of the situation and the rapid blood loss, immediate surgical intervention is necessary.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Conservative for next 6 hours: Conservative management involves monitoring and treating the patient without immediate surgical intervention. However, in a case of heavy bleeding with ongoing blood loss, waiting for 6 hours is not appropriate. This delay could lead to further deterioration and worsening of the patient's condition.

Option C - Continue resuscitation: While resuscitation is important, in a situation with significant and ongoing blood loss as described, simply continuing resuscitation without addressing the underlying cause (bleeding) may not be effective. Direct intervention to control the bleeding is crucial.

Option D - Wait & watch: Waiting and watching the patient's condition without taking immediate action to control the bleeding could be dangerous in this scenario. The patient is actively bleeding with a large volume of blood loss, which requires prompt intervention to stabilize their condition.

questions.text: In a patient with aortic dissection, injury to which of the following structure will cause hiccups?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Phrenic nerve: 

  • In a patient with aortic dissection, injury to the phrenic nerve can cause hiccups.
  • Phrenic nerve receives contributions from the cervical nerve roots (C3-C5) and travels along the mediastinum and pericardium, running close to the thoracic aorta.
  • An aortic dissection, particularly involving the ascending aorta or arch, can lead to irritation or compression of the phrenic nerve, causing it to become hyperactive.
  • This hyperactivity can manifest as hiccups, which are involuntary contractions of the diaphragm.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following are features of pseudohallucinations, except?

choices.text: They are perceived in the outer objective space

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- They are perceived in the outer objective space:

  • This statement is incorrect. Pseudohallucinations are not perceived in the objective space. They are typically perceived in the subjective or internal space of the individual's mind. These perceptions might seem real to the person experiencing them, but they are not projected into the external environment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- They occur without external stimulus: Pseudohallucinations are defined as perceptions that occur without an external stimulus. In other words, the individual experiences sensory perceptions that seem real but are not triggered by any actual external input. This can be contrasted with true hallucinations, which are perceptions without external stimuli but are experienced as if they are real.

Option C- They are not vivid: hallucinations are often described as vivid and intense sensory experiences. While they are not based on external stimuli, they can still be very detailed and realistic to the person experiencing them. This vividness contributes to the confusion between pseudohallucinations and true hallucinations.

Option D- They are done voluntarily: Pseudohallucinations, like true hallucinations, are  under the control of the individual experiencing them. They occur voluntarily and are often distressing to the person. The lack of control distinguishes hallucinations from imagination or deliberate thought processes.

questions.text: A 45 year old patient with a history of kidney stones that were surgically removed 2 years ago presents with complaints of fever and flank pain. Imaging done is shown here. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cystoscopic retrieval of foreign Body:

  • The given image is of foreign body in bladder.
  • Cystoscopy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves inserting a thin tube with a camera (cystoscope) into the urinary tract to visualize and potentially remove foreign bodies or stones. This option seems reasonable if the imaging has revealed the presence of a foreign body in the urinary tract and it's contributing to the patient's symptoms. Cystoscopic retrieval is a less invasive approach compared to open surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Laparotomy to remove the stones: Laparotomy involves making a surgical incision in the abdominal wall to access the internal organs. It is generally not the first-line approach for kidney stone removal. Kidney stones can often be managed through less invasive methods such as lithotripsy or endoscopic procedures. Laparotomy might be considered in very complex or unusual cases but is not usually the initial choice.

Option B - Lithotripsy to remove recurrent stone: Lithotripsy is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break down kidney stones into smaller fragments that can be passed naturally. It's a common approach for kidney stone management, especially when the stones are relatively small. If the patient has recurrent kidney stones, lithotripsy could be a reasonable option depending on the size, location, and composition of the stones.

Option C - Leave the foreign body inside: Leaving a foreign body inside the body is generally not a recommended approach, especially if it is causing symptoms such as fever and flank pain. Foreign bodies can lead to complications like infection, obstruction, or damage to the surrounding tissues. Removing the foreign body would be a more appropriate course of action if it's contributing to the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient on psychiatric medication developed a sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine. He is on antidepressants. Which of the following drug the person be taking?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - MAO inhibitors (monoamine oxidase inhibitors):

  • MAO inhibitors are a class of antidepressant medications that work by inhibiting the activity of the enzyme monoamine oxidase, which breaks down neurotransmitters like serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine.
  • These medications can interact with certain foods and beverages, including wine, that contain tyramine.
  • Consuming tyramine-rich foods and beverages while on MAO inhibitors can lead to a sudden and severe increase in blood pressure, known as a hypertensive crisis.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D do not cause hypertensive crisis when combined with wine.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to a psychiatrist with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite and difficulty sleeping for 2 months. The diagnosis of a major depressive disorder is made by the psychiatrist. Which drug is best for the above-mentioned disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Fluoxetine:

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).
  • SSRIs are recommended as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder due to their efficacy in alleviating depressive symptoms.
  • It works by increasing the availability of serotonin in the brain, which can help improve mood, appetite, and sleep patterns.

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are not used in treatment for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids and the manometry findings include uncoordinated or absent peristalsis with increased LES resting pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Achalasia cardia 

  • Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus where there is impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), which leads to difficulty in moving food from the esophagus into the stomach.
  • This disorder often presents with symptoms like regurgitation of undigested food, difficulty swallowing solids and liquids and chest pain.

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of HTN came in with complaints of headaches for five days. All classical signs, increased metanephrine levels, and other investigations indicate pheochromocytoma. What is the best imaging modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - MIBG

  • MIBG scintigraphy helps locate and visualize pheochromocytomas or paragangliomas, even in cases where these tumors may not be easily seen with other imaging methods. It is particularly valuable for detecting extra-adrenal (paragangliomas) and metastatic lesions. It is valuable for confirming the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma, assessing the extent of disease (staging), and identifying the presence of metastases to other areas of the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) Chest and Abdomen: CECT provides detailed cross-sectional images of the chest and abdomen, allowing visualization of the adrenal glands and any potential tumors. It can help determine the size, location, and characteristics of the tumor, as well as its potential involvement with nearby structures. But it is not IOC for pheochromocytoma

Option B - Sestamibi Scan: Sestamibi scans are typically used for parathyroid imaging and localizing certain types of tumors. They are not the most appropriate imaging modality for pheochromocytoma evaluation.

Option D - USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound may be used as an initial screening tool for certain abdominal conditions, but it is not the preferred imaging modality for diagnosing or localizing pheochromocytoma. This may not provide the level of detail needed to assess the adrenal glands and surrounding structures

questions.text: Which fluid is administered most commonly during intraoperative blood loss?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Crystalloids: 

  • Crystalloids are the most commonly administered fluid for intraoperative fluid administration, especially in minor surgical procedures.
  • Crystalloids are cost-effective, readily available, and generally safe.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with abdominal pain in the emergency room. . On examination, there is blackish discoloration involving the periumbilical skin. What is the most likely diagnosis for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A - Acute Pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is characterized by inflammation of the pancreas and can cause severe abdominal pain. However, it typically doesn't lead to blackish discoloration of the perineal skin. Hypotension may occur in severe cases due to systemic inflammation and fluid shifts, but the perineal discoloration is not a common feature of acute pancreatitis.

  • Presents with cullens sign

Incorrect Options:

 Option B - Necrotizing Fasciitis:

  • Deeper tissue injury, usually from anaerobic bacteria or S pyogenes. Pain may be out of proportion to exam findings.
  • Results in crepitus from methane and CO2 production.
  • “Flesh-eating bacteria.” Causes bullae and skin necrosis causing violaceous color of bullae, surrounding skin .
  • Surgical emergency

Option C - Chronic Pancreatitis: Chronic pancreatitis is a long-standing inflammation of the pancreas, often due to alcohol abuse or other underlying factors. It leads to persistent abdominal pain, digestive issues, and potentially complications over time. However, it is unlikely to cause the rapid onset of perineal skin discoloration and hypotension as seen in the given presentation.

Option D - Traumatic Fat Necrosis: Traumatic fat necrosis can occur as a result of physical trauma to fatty tissues, leading to localized inflammation and tissue damage. While it can cause skin discoloration, it typically presents as a localized issue rather than involving the perineal skin. It's also less likely to cause the severe systemic symptoms, including hypotension, seen in this case.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption is admitted to the hospital with features of confusion, vision loss and an unsteady gait. He is unable to remember the most recent incidents. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Thiamine (Vitamin B1):

  • Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine deficiency due to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption.
  • This disorder is known as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and is characterized by confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confabulation and amnesia.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C): Ascorbic acid deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by weakness, joint pain, bleeding gums, and skin changes.

Option B - Retinol (Vitamin A): Retinol deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, and vision-related issues.

Option D - Folate (Vitamin B9): Folate deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in pregnant women.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is depicted in the given CT image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia

  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a genetic disorder that affects the adrenal glands, leading to problems with hormone production. CAH is often diagnosed through newborn screening programs, which aim to detect hormone imbalances shortly after birth. Genetic testing and hormone level assessments are also used for diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cirrhosis: Cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism. It can lead to various structural changes in the liver, but these changes might not be directly visible on a single CT image.

Option B - HCC (Hepatocellular Carcinoma): Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common type of primary liver cancer. It often occurs in the context of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis. On a CT scan, HCC may appear as a mass or a lesion within the liver. The appearance can vary, but it might have characteristics like enhancing in the arterial phase and washout in the delayed phase on contrast-enhanced scans.

Option D - Hepatitis: Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver, often caused by viral infections. On a CT scan, the liver might appear enlarged and have altered density due to inflammation, but specific visual characteristics might not be definitive for a hepatitis diagnosis. Other diagnostic methods, such as blood tests and clinical history, are usually necessary

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient had a RTA and was brought to the ER. On examination, his GCS was E2M4V2 and his CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Craniotomy with evacuation of hematoma 

  • CT scan shows extradural hematoma.
  • Extradural hematoma causes increased intracranial pressure, leading to brain compression and potential life-threatening complications.
  • Craniotomy with evacuation of hematoma can relieve pressure on the brain and prevent further damage.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are not the treatment of extradural hematoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presented with varicose veins. What is the investigation of choice for varicose veins?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Duplex scan:

  • Duplex scan is the investigation of choice for varicose veins.
  • It is a non-invasive imaging technique that combines conventional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasound.
  • It allows visualization of blood flow in the veins and can identify abnormalities, such as reflux (backward flow of blood) in the veins, which is a common finding in varicose veins.
  • It provides valuable information about the anatomy and function of the veins, helping to guide treatment decisions.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Plethysmography:

  • Plethysmography is a technique used to measure changes in the volume of an organ or limb.
  • While it can provide information about blood volume changes, it is not as specific or accurate in diagnosing the underlying causes of varicose veins as duplex ultrasound.

Option C - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging):

  • While MRI can provide detailed images of soft tissues, it is usually reserved for more complex cases or when other imaging methods are inconclusive.
  • Duplex ultrasound is preferred due to its cost-effectiveness and accuracy in diagnosing varicose veins.

Option D - CT (Computed Tomography):

  • CT scans involve ionizing radiation and are generally used for specific indications.
  • Duplex ultrasound is safer, non-invasive and more suitable for evaluating venous abnormalities like varicose veins.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents after undergoing a Billroth II gastrectomy operation and complains of symptoms suggestive of dumping syndrome, including vomiting and diarrhea occurring approximately 20 minutes after meals. What should be the initial management for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Reverse Billroth II to Billroth I

questions.solution:
Correct option B - Small frequent meals

  • Dumping syndrome is commonly seen after gastric surgery, such as Billroth II gastrectomy, where the pyloric valve is removed, leading to rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine.
  • Consuming smaller, more frequent meals can help slow down the rate of stomach emptying, reducing the severity of symptoms like vomiting and diarrhea.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Low fat diet: A low fat diet might help to some extent, but the primary issue in dumping syndrome is the rapid emptying of the stomach, not necessarily the fat content of the food.

Option C - Insulin and protein: Insulin and protein are not used as management for dumping syndrome.

Option D - Reverse Billroth II to Billroth I:

  • Reversing the surgical procedure to convert a Billroth II to a Billroth I gastrectomy is a major surgical decision that is generally not the initial management choice for dumping syndrome.
  • Non-surgical approaches, like dietary modifications, are usually tried first.

questions.text: What is the Intubation of choice in a Maxillofacial trauma patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tracheostomy:

  • Tracheostomy involves creating a surgical airway directly into the trachea through the neck. While it provides a secure airway, it's generally not the initial choice for managing airways in maxillofacial trauma patients unless there are specific indications, such as severe facial fractures that prevent other methods of intubation. Tracheostomy is considered a more invasive procedure and is usually reserved for situations where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA): Laryngeal mask airway is a supraglottic airway device that is less invasive than tracheostomy. It sits in the pharynx and seals around the laryngeal inlet, allowing positive pressure ventilation. However, in cases of significant maxillofacial trauma, proper placement and effective ventilation might be compromised due to anatomical disruptions and bleeding.

Option C - Orotracheal Intubation: Orotracheal intubation involves passing an endotracheal tube through the mouth into the trachea. It provides a secure airway and is often the preferred choice for managing maxillofacial trauma patients, as it bypasses the potential obstacles created by facial fractures, allowing effective ventilation and protection of the airway.

Option D - Mask Ventilation: Mask ventilation involves using a bag-mask device to manually deliver positive pressure ventilation to a patient. While it might be used temporarily in situations where intubation is difficult, it's not the intubation method itself. In maxillofacial trauma, mask ventilation can be challenging due to disrupted facial anatomy and potential difficulty in achieving a proper seal.

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the insertion of the intercostal tube drain?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Upper border of lower rib 

  • The upper border of lower rib is the most preferred site because it helps to avoid injury to important structures like the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the rib.
  • By inserting the needle just above the upper border of the lower rib, there's a decreased risk of damaging these structures.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are not the preferred sites for the insertion of intercostal tube drain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with chills and rigors. She has acute pain in right flank region. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Emphysematous pyelonephritis:

  • Emphysematous pyelonephritis is a severe bacterial infection of the kidney characterized by gas formation within the renal parenchyma and surrounding tissues.
  • It is more common in patients with diabetes and is associated with high mortality.
  • The patient's presentation of chills, rigors, acute right flank pain and the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma on imaging are highly indicative of emphysematous pyelonephritis.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: Which part of cranial fossa is injured in Raccoon eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Anterior cranial fossa 

  • Raccoon eyes, also known as periorbital ecchymosis, is a condition where bruising and discoloration occur around the eyes.
  • In cases of trauma or fractures involving the anterior cranial fossa, blood from the injury can accumulate and spread within the periorbital tissues, leading to the characteristic raccoon eye appearance.

Incorrect options: Option A, C and D are not associated with raccoon eyes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with urinary complaints. He has a history of working in a dye factory in the past. On USG examination, his bladder walls are found to be thickened and irregular. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Radical Cystectomy:

  • Radical cystectomy is the surgical removal of the entire bladder. This option is the most appropriate choice based on the patient's history of working in a dye factory, urinary complaints, and findings of thickened and irregular bladder walls. Exposure to certain chemicals, such as those used in dye factories, can increase the risk of bladder cancer. The presentation suggests a potential malignancy, and radical cystectomy is a definitive treatment for invasive bladder cancer that hasn't responded to more conservative treatments. It involves removing the bladder along with nearby lymph nodes and, in some cases, other adjacent organs. This procedure is reserved for cases where the cancer has invaded the bladder wall or has a high likelihood of spreading.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Instillation of BCG: Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) instillation is a treatment commonly used for superficial bladder cancer and not for urinary complaints related to thickened and irregular bladder walls. BCG is a type of immunotherapy that helps stimulate the immune system to fight cancer cells. It is not appropriate for this patient's presentation.

Option B - Cystoscopy with Tumor Removal: While cystoscopy with tumor removal is indicated for patients with bladder tumors or suspected bladder cancer, this patient's presentation of urinary complaints, thickened, and irregular bladder walls is not indicative of a tumor. Therefore, this option is not the most appropriate management for this patient.

Option C - Intravesical Mitomycin C: Intravesical mitomycin C is a treatment option for superficial bladder cancer, similar to BCG instillation. It is not typically used for urinary complaints related to thickened and irregular bladder walls. Thus, it's not the most suitable choice for this patient.

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting. Which sign is depicted in the following radiograph?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Double bubble sign:

  • The double bubble sign is a radiological finding seen on an abdominal X-ray or ultrasound in cases of duodenal atresia or stenosis.
  • It is characterized by the presence of two distinct air-filled bubbles in the abdomen: one representing the stomach and the other representing the dilated portion of the proximal duodenum.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Air crescent sign:

  • The air crescent sign is typically seen in radiological imaging of patients with invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • It appears as a crescent-shaped pocket of air surrounding a lung nodule or cavity.

Option C - Cupola sign:

  • The cupola sign is seen on a supine chest or abdominal radiograph in the presence of pneumoperitoneum.
  • It refers to non-dependent gas that rises within the abdominal cavity of the supine patient to accumulate underneath the central tendon of the diaphragm in the midline.

Option D - Triple bubble sign:

  • The triple bubble sign is the classic radiographic appearance observed in jejunal atresia.
  • The appearance is due to a proximal obstruction caused by the atretic jejunum.

questions.text: A 39-year-old female presented in the OPD with bloody discharge from the nipple. On examination, it was found to be from a single lactiferous duct. What is the treatment for bloody nipple discharge with single duct involvement?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Microdochectomy 

  • Microdochectomy involves the surgical removal of the affected lactiferous duct.
  • It is the treatment of choice for cases of bloody nipple discharge originating from a single duct.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Hadfield’s procedure:

  • Hadfield's procedure is an obsolete surgical procedure used in the past for the treatment of mammary duct ectasia.
  • It is not used for bloody nipple discharge from a single duct.

Option C - Microdiscectomy: Microdiscectomy is a surgical procedure used to treat herniated spinal discs that are pressing on nerves.

Option D - IV antibiotics + Incision: It is considered in cases of infection-related symptoms or abscesses in the breast and is not the primary treatment for bloody nipple discharge with single duct involvement.

questions.text: What is the best investigation to assess renal perfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - DTPA (diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid) scan

  • It is a nuclear medicine test that involves injecting a radioactive tracer (DTPA) into the bloodstream.
  • The tracer is taken up by the kidneys and then its distribution and clearance are monitored using gamma camera imaging.
  • This allows for the assessment of renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and overall renal perfusion.
  • It is particularly useful in diagnosing conditions like renal artery stenosis or renal vascular disorders that affect renal perfusion.

Incorrect options:

Option B - DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan:

  • DMSA scan is used to assess the functioning of the renal parenchyma.
  • It is used to diagnose or monitor kidney infections and scarring.

Option C - RGU (retrograde urethrogram): RGU is an imaging test used to visualize the urethra and the urinary bladder.

Option D - CT urogram:

  • CT urogram is a radiological examination that involves the use of a contrast dye to visualize the urinary tract structures, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
  • It is more focused on detecting structural abnormalities.

questions.text: A patient presented with a head injury after a hammer fell on the skull. CT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Depressed skull fracture:

  • A depressed skull fracture occurs when a portion of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • This type of fracture often occurs from blunt trauma to the head, such as being hit by a heavy object.

Incorrect options: Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and left flank pain. CT scan of the abdomen was performed and the image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Horseshoe kidney:

  • In a horseshoe kidney, during fetal development, the lower poles of both kidneys fuse, creating a U-shaped structure that is located below the level of the normal kidneys.
  • CT scan shows the fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys, with both kidneys located in proximity in the midline of the abdomen, appearing as a single mass.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of correct answer.

questions.text: A patient has a painless, palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone. X-ray done shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Osteochondroma:

  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that arises from the surface of a bone near the metaphysis and occurs in individuals during their growth years.
  • It presents as a painless, palpable bony mass that grows away from the joint.
  • On an X-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bony outgrowth with a cartilage cap.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that primarily affects the metaphysis of long bones.
  • It usually presents with a painful, rapidly growing mass.
  • On an X-ray, osteosarcoma typically appears as a destructive and irregular lesion with aggressive features such as periosteal reaction, cortical destruction and soft tissue extension.

Option B - Multiple myeloma:

  • Multiple myeloma is a hematological malignancy that affects plasma cells in the bone marrow.
  • It does not present as a palpable bony mass near the metaphysis of a long bone.
  • On an X-ray, multiple myeloma can show lytic lesions throughout the bone, often referred to as "punched-out" lesions.

Option D - Osteoid osteoma

  • Osteoid osteoma is a benign bone tumor that causes localized pain that is relieved by NSAIDs.
  • It is typically found in the cortex of long bones, rather than near the metaphysis.
  • On an X-ray, osteoid osteoma appears as a small radiolucent nidus surrounded by dense sclerotic bone.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is damaged in the picture of the patient given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Radial nerve:

  • Radial nerve is responsible for providing motor function to the muscles that extend the wrist and fingers, as well as sensory innervation to the back of the hand.
  • Damage to the radial nerve can result in a condition known as "wrist drop," where the muscles that control wrist extension become weakened or paralyzed.
  • This leads to difficulty lifting the wrist and fingers, and the hand may hang down in a limp or dropped position.

Incorrect options: 

Option B - Ulnar nerve:

  • Ulnar nerve supplies motor function to the muscles of the hand responsible for fine motor movements and also provides sensory innervation to the little finger and part of the ring finger.
  • Damage to the ulnar nerve can lead to issues such as "claw hand," where the muscles controlling finger flexion are affected, causing a characteristic claw-like hand deformity.

Option C - Median nerve:

  • Median nerve innervates muscles that control flexion of the wrist and fingers, as well as providing sensory innervation to the palm and fingers.
  • Damage to the median nerve can cause symptoms such as pain, tingling, and weakness in the thumb, index, middle and ring fingers. 

Option D - Axillary Nerve:

  • Axillary nerve supplies the deltoid muscle, which is responsible for lifting the arm to the side.
  • Damage to the axillary nerve can result in weakness or paralysis of the deltoid muscle, leading to difficulty lifting the arm to the side.

questions.text: What condition is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Biceps tendon rupture

  • The image shows Popeye's sign.
  • Popeye's sign is a classic sign for proximal biceps tendon rupture.

Incorrect options: Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: An 11-year-old patient presents with an outward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm. The patient reports occasional discomfort and limitation in the range of motion of the affected arm. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Cubitus valgus

  • This condition is characterized by an outward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm.
  • It typically results from a malunion of the distal humerus after a fracture, causing the forearm to deviate away from the midline of the body.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Cubitus varus:

  • This condition involves an inward angulation of the forearm in relation to the upper arm.
  • It is seen after a fracture of the distal humerus in children.
  • In cubitus varus, the forearm is deviated towards the midline of the body.

Option C - Gunstock deformity:

  • This is often used interchangeably with cubitus varus.
  • It refers to an inward angulation of the forearm due to a malunion of the distal humerus after a fracture.
  • The forearm appears bent, resembling the shape of a gunstock.

Option D - Coxa vara: This condition pertains to the hip joint and involves a decrease in the angle between the head and neck of the femur, leading to an inward angulation of the thigh bone.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a noticeable deformity of the neck and upper back. On physical examination, the patient's scapula is observed to be elevated and medially rotated, giving it the appearance of an equilateral triangle. The patient also has limited neck mobility. The patient and their family report that the deformity has been present since birth and has not improved over time. What is the likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Klippel-Feil deformity:

  • This congenital condition involves a fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae, resulting in a short neck and limited neck mobility.
  • The characteristic "triangular" appearance of the neck due to scapular elevation and medial rotation is a hallmark of Klippel-Feil deformity.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Separated shoulder deformity: This refers to a type of shoulder injury where the acromioclavicular joint is sprained or dislocated due to trauma.

Option B - Torticollis: Torticollis, also known as wry neck, is a condition characterized by the abnormal positioning or tilting of the head, often due to muscle spasms or contractures.

Option D - Congenital scoliosi: Congenital scoliosis is a lateral curvature of the spine that is present at birth and is due to malformations of the vertebrae. It can cause asymmetry in the shoulders and hips but does not typically present with the specific elevated and medially rotated scapula described in the question

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following test is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Thomas test:

  • This test is used to assess the presence of hip flexion contracture and to measure hip extension.
  • If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option C - Telescopy:

  • Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing for abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement.

 

Option B - Lasegue test:

  • Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression.

 

Option D - McMurray test:

  • Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear.

questions.text: Which carcinoma is the possible diagnosis in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Malignant melanoma

  • It presents as an irregularly shaped, dark-colored lesion with uneven borders.
  • Malignant melanoma has a higher potential to metastasize if not detected and treated early.
  • It is crucial to catch it at an early stage for a better prognosis.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Basal cell carcinoma:

  • It appears as a flesh-colored or pinkish bump with a central depression and raised edges.
  • It is slow-growing and rarely metastasizes.
  • It is common in areas exposed to the sun.

Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • It is also linked to sun exposure.
  • It presents as a firm, red nodule or a scaly, crusted lesion.
  • It has a higher potential to metastasize if left untreated.

Option D - Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma is a type of liver cancer that originates from hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the OPD with a history of prolonged use of steroids for a skin condition. The patient complains of an expanding rash that has become less red and itchy since using the steroids. On examination, there are well-defined, slightly raised, erythematous plaques with central clearing and a scaly border on various parts of the body. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tinea incognito

  • Tinea incognito is a term used to describe fungal infections, specifically tinea (ringworm), that have been modified or worsened due to the inappropriate use of topical steroids. In this case, the patient's history of prolonged steroid use has likely led to the modification of the typical clinical appearance of the fungal infection.
  • The expanding rash, reduced redness and itchiness, well-defined slightly raised plaques with central clearing, and scaly border all point to tinea incognito.
  • The use of steroids can mask the inflammatory response and alter the clinical presentation, making it challenging to recognize the underlying fungal infection.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Tinea corporis:

  • Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal infection of the skin characterized by red, itchy, circular, or oval lesions with an active border and central clearing.
  • While the patient's presentation does involve some elements seen in tinea corporis (such as well-defined plaques and central clearing), the fact that the patient has been using steroids and the alteration of the typical symptoms makes tinea incognito a more appropriate diagnosis in this case.

Option C - Tinea cruris:

  • Tinea cruris, commonly referred to as jock itch, is a fungal infection that affects the groin and inner thighs.
  • It typically presents as red, scaly, and sometimes itchy lesions with well-defined borders.
  • The patient's symptoms are not limited to the groin area, and the modification of symptoms due to steroid use suggests a different diagnosis.

Option D - Tinea pedis:

  • Tinea pedis, also known as athlete's foot, is a fungal infection affecting the feet.
  • It can cause redness, itching, and scaling between the toes and on the soles of the feet.
  • The patient's presentation involves lesions on various parts of the body and the modification of symptoms due to steroid use, which makes tinea incognito a more suitable diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following instrument is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Veress Needle:

  • The Veress needle is commonly used for creating pneumoperitoneum and facilitating initial entry into the abdominal cavity during laparoscopic surgery. Pneumoperitoneum is the process of filling the abdominal cavity with carbon dioxide gas to create a working space for laparoscopic instruments. The Veress needle is inserted through a small incision or puncture in the abdominal wall, and carbon dioxide gas is insufflated into the abdominal cavity. This technique allows for safe and controlled entry into the peritoneal cavity before other laparoscopic instruments are introduced.

Hasson Cannula (Option B): The Hasson cannula is another instrument used for entry into the abdominal cavity during laparoscopic surgery. It involves making a small incision in the abdominal wall and inserting the cannula under direct visualization. The cannula is secured in place, and carbon dioxide gas is then insufflated to create pneumoperitoneum. While the Hasson cannula is a valid method of entry, the Veress needle is more commonly used due to its less invasive nature.

Large Bore Cannula (Option C): A large bore cannula is not typically used for creating pneumoperitoneum and initial entry into the abdominal cavity. Large bore cannulas are generally used for suction and irrigation during laparoscopic procedures.

Small Bore Cannula (Option D): A small bore cannula is also not commonly used for creating pneumoperitoneum and initial entry. Small bore cannulas might be used for specific tasks during laparoscopic surgery, but they are not the primary instrument for establishing the pneumoperitoneum and entering the abdominal cavity.

questions.text:
In a 45-year-old patient undergoing a preoperative assessment for a surgical procedure, which classification of Mallampati score is assigned based on the following description:
Hard palate, soft palate, uvula, tip of the uvula, and tonsil pillars are visible. No oropharyngeal structures are obstructing the view.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Grade I:

  • In the scenario described, the entire soft palate, uvula, pillars, and tonsillar region can be seen without any obstruction. The correct classification is Grade I. This indicates an optimal airway visualization and ease of intubation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Grade II: Hard palate, soft palate, uvula, and tonsil pillars are visible. The tip of the uvula is not visible. 

Option C- Grade III: Hard palate, soft palate, base of the uvula are visible.

Option D- Grade IV: Only hard palate is visible.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old patient who has just experienced a cardiac arrest, which of the following interventions is not a part of the Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support (ACLS) protocol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Soda Bicarbonate:

  • While sodium bicarbonate used to be a part of ACLS protocols in the past, its use has become more limited in recent guidelines.
  • It was commonly used to correct acidosis (increased acidity) during cardiac arrest.
  • However, current evidence suggests that routine use of sodium bicarbonate in cardiac arrest may not provide significant benefits and could potentially cause harm.
  • Therefore, it is no longer routinely recommended in ACLS protocols, especially in cases of cardiac arrest due to non-hypoxic causes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Amiodarone: Amiodarone is included in the ACLS protocol and is used for the treatment of certain types of irregular heart rhythms, particularly ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia that are resistant to other interventions. It helps stabilize the heart's electrical activity.

Option B- Defibrillation: Defibrillation is a critical component of the ACLS protocol. It involves delivering an electric shock to the heart to reset its electrical rhythm in cases of ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia, which are life-threatening arrhythmias that can lead to cardiac arrest.

Option C- Adrenaline: Adrenaline (also known as epinephrine) is an essential medication in the ACLS protocol. It is used to stimulate the heart and blood vessels, increasing heart rate and blood pressure. It is administered during cardiac arrest to improve blood flow to vital organs.

questions.text: Which vertebral level corresponds to Tuffier’s line, a clinically relevant anatomical landmark?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- L4-L5:

  • This is the correct vertebral level corresponding to Tuffier's line. Tuffier's line is drawn between the highest points of the iliac crests, and it usually intersects the spine at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) or the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). It is an important reference for lumbar punctures because it helps determine the appropriate level for inserting the needle into the spinal canal without risk of damaging the spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- L2-L3: This vertebral level is not relevant to Tuffier's line. Tuffier's line, also known as the intercristal line, is an anatomical landmark that corresponds to the highest point of the iliac crests. It is used as a reference point for lumbar punctures (spinal taps). L2-L3 would not be the correct level for Tuffier's line.

Option C- L5-S1: This vertebral level is not directly related to Tuffier's line. Tuffier's line is typically drawn above the level of L5-S1, as it corresponds to the highest points of the iliac crests. Lumbar punctures are usually performed below L5-S1, at the L3-L4 or L4-L5 level.

Option D- L3-L4: This vertebral level is close to the correct answer but not exactly accurate. While Tuffier's line intersects the spine around the L4-L5 level, some sources might mention L3-L4 as an approximate reference point. However, the more precise and commonly accepted landmark is L4-L5.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a generalized vesicular rash covering the entire body. The child's parents report that the rash started as red spots and quickly developed into fluid-filled blisters. The child also has a mild fever and is feeling irritable. What is the most likely diagnosis for this child's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Varicella

  • This is the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described. Varicella is a viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It typically presents with a generalized vesicular rash that starts as red spots and quickly develops into fluid-filled blisters. The child may also have a mild fever and feel irritable. Chickenpox is common in children and is highly contagious. The vesicles eventually crust over and heal. It's important to note that a vaccine is available for varicella, which has greatly reduced the incidence of the disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Shingles (Herpes Zoster): Shingles is also caused by the varicella-zoster virus. However, it typically occurs in adults who had chickenpox earlier in life. Shingles presents as a painful, localized vesicular rash along a specific dermatome (nerve pathway). It is less likely in a 3-year-old child and would present differently than the generalized rash described in the scenario.

Option C - Smallpox: Smallpox is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the variola virus. However, smallpox has been eradicated from the general population due to successful vaccination efforts, and it hasn't been reported since the late 1970s. The symptoms and presentation of smallpox are different from the scenario described.

Option D - Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease that affects the muscles and skin. It typically presents with muscle weakness and a characteristic skin rash, but the rash pattern and symptoms are distinct from the generalized vesicular rash described in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct for the device depicted below:

choices.text: Based on infrared emitted from RBCs
Checks thickness of artery and vein

questions.solution:
Correct option A - Based on infrared emitted from RBCs:

  • The device depicted is a Doppler ultrasound machine, which uses sound waves and not infrared emitted from RBCs, to create images of blood flow.
  • Doppler ultrasound works by measuring the frequency shift of sound waves reflected off moving red blood cells.
  • This shift in frequency, known as the Doppler effect, helps in visualizing blood flow direction and velocity.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Localizes calcified plaque:

  • Doppler ultrasound can identify areas of calcified plaque within blood vessels.
  • However, it might not provide as detailed information about the plaque compared to other imaging techniques like CT scans or angiography.

Option C - Checks blood flow : Doppler ultrasound is primarily used for assessing blood flow and vascular conditions. 

Option D - Checks thickness of artery and vein:

  • Doppler ultrasound can be used to measure the thickness of arteries and veins, as well as assess their overall structure and condition.
  • It is particularly useful for evaluating conditions like atherosclerosis, where arteries might become thicker due to plaque buildup.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhoea and alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Zinc

  • Zinc deficiency can indeed cause poor wound healing, dermatitis (inflammation of the skin), diarrhea, and alopecia (hair loss).
  • Zinc is essential for immune function, wound healing, and maintaining healthy skin and hair.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Iron: Iron deficiency is associated with anemia, fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. It can lead to reduced oxygen transport in the body, causing symptoms like tiredness, shortness of breath, and cold extremities.

Option B - Calcium: Calcium deficiency can result in weak bones, brittle nails, and muscle cramps. It's crucial for maintaining bone health and proper muscle function.

Option C - Magnesium: Magnesium deficiency may lead to muscle spasms, irregular heartbeat, and weakness. It plays a role in nerve transmission and muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a bluish translucent extravasation cystic sublingual swelling. The swelling is accompanied by visible veins over the swelling and is transilluminant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Ranula:

  • Ranula is a cyst that forms within the floor of the mouth, often beneath the tongue.
  • It is caused by the obstruction of a salivary gland duct.
  • It appears bluish-translucent due to the accumulation of saliva within the cyst.
  • There are visible veins over it due to increased pressure on the surrounding blood vessels.
  • It is a transilluminant swelling.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Thyroglossal cyst:

  • Thyroglossal cysts are congenital fluid-filled swellings that form along the path where the thyroid gland migrates during fetal development.
  • They appear in the midline of the neck, above the hyoid bone.
  • They neither present as bluish-translucent cystic sublingual swellings nor do they involve the sublingual area.

Option B - Dermoid cyst:

  • Dermoid cysts are benign tumors that contain a variety of tissues, including skin, hair, and sometimes even teeth.
  • They are typically present at birth and slowly grow over time.
  • Dermoid cysts are not located in the sublingual area and do not usually cause visible veins overlying the area.

Option D - Sublingual tumor: This refers to a tumor or growth occurring in the sublingual area.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a facial appearance that is marked by thickened, coarse, and deeply furrowed skin. The skin appears to be involved in the cheeks, forehead, and nose. The patient complains of numbness and weakness in the extremities. On examination, there are hypopigmented and erythematous patches with loss of sensation. What is the medical condition characterized by the term “Leonine facies”?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lepromatous Leprosy

  • "Leonine facies" is a term used to describe a specific facial appearance that can be seen in patients with advanced lepromatous leprosy. Lepromatous leprosy is a severe form of leprosy caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium leprae. It is characterized by the infiltration of the skin and other tissues by large numbers of bacilli, leading to significant tissue damage and deformities. The term "leonine" refers to the resemblance of the patient's facial features to those of a lion, with thickened, coarse, deeply furrowed skin. In addition to the distinct facial appearance, lepromatous leprosy can lead to peripheral nerve damage, resulting in sensory loss, muscle weakness, and other neurological symptoms. The hypopigmented and erythematous patches with loss of sensation mentioned in the patient's presentation are also characteristic of leprosy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acromegaly: Acromegaly is a condition caused by the excessive production of growth hormone after the growth plates have closed. It leads to the enlargement of bones and tissues, resulting in enlarged hands, feet, facial features, and other body parts. While acromegaly can cause changes in facial appearance, it does not typically result in the specific "leonine facies" described in the question.

Option C - Myasthenia Gravis: Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly in the muscles that control eye and eyelid movements, facial expression, chewing, and swallowing. It does not cause the thickened, coarse, and deeply furrowed skin seen in "leonine facies."

Option D - Bell's Palsy: Bell's palsy is a condition characterized by sudden weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face due to inflammation of the facial nerve. It can lead to drooping of the affected side of the face and difficulty in facial expressions, but it does not cause the specific skin changes described as "leonine facies."

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a swelling in the subhyoid region of the neck that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the recommended treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sistrunk's operation:

  • The given features in the question stem lead to the diagnosis of Thyroglossal duct cyst. 
  • Sistrunk's operation is a surgical procedure used to treat a thyroglossal duct cyst.
  •  Thyroglossal duct cyst is a developmental anomaly resulting from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct. This cyst can present as a swelling in the subhyoid region of the neck that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion.
  • Sistrunk's operation involves removing the cyst, along with a portion of the hyoid bone and the central portion of the body of the hyoid bone. This procedure helps prevent recurrence and ensures complete removal of the cyst.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total thyroidectomy: This option is not appropriate for the given scenario. Total thyroidectomy involves the complete removal of the thyroid gland, which is not indicated for a swelling in the subhyoid region of the neck that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion. Additionally, total thyroidectomy is not a suitable approach for a pediatric patient without proper indications.

Option B - Ramstedt's operation: Ramstedt's operation, also known as pyloromyotomy, is a surgical procedure performed to treat pyloric stenosis, which is a condition affecting the stomach's outlet. This option is not relevant to the given scenario of a swelling in the subhyoid region of the neck.

Option C - Hemi-thyroidectomy: Hemi-thyroidectomy involves the removal of half of the thyroid gland. This option is also not appropriate for the situation described. The subhyoid swelling is not related to the thyroid gland and its removal would not address the issue.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is scheduled to undergo laparoscopic surgery. The surgical team plans to create a pneumoperitoneum to facilitate the procedure. Which gas is commonly used for creating the pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Carbon dioxide:

  • Laparoscopic surgery is a minimally invasive surgical technique in which small incisions are made in the abdominal wall to insert a camera and surgical instruments. A pneumoperitoneum, which is the inflation of the abdominal cavity with gas, is created to create space for the surgeon to work and to provide a clear view of the surgical site. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the gas commonly used for creating the pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Helium: Helium is a noble gas that is lighter than air, but it is not commonly used for creating a pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. Helium is expensive and can lead to difficulties in accurately maintaining the desired pressure within the abdominal cavity.

Option B - Oxygen: Oxygen is not used for creating a pneumoperitoneum. It is not suitable for this purpose because it can support combustion, and the risk of fire or explosion would be a concern in a surgical setting.

Option C - Nitrogen: While nitrogen is an inert gas and is commonly found in the atmosphere, it is not the gas of choice for creating a pneumoperitoneum. Carbon dioxide is preferred over nitrogen due to its ability to be rapidly absorbed by the body if it enters the bloodstream, which reduces the risk of gas embolism.

questions.text: The involvement of which of the following results in the given condition below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymphatics

  • The correct answer is lymphatics. Filariasis is a disease caused by parasitic worms, specifically Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori. These worms primarily inhabit the lymphatic system, causing inflammation and obstruction of lymphatic vessels. This leads to the clinical manifestations of filariasis, such as lymphedema (swelling), elephantiasis (severe swelling), and other related complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Arteries: Arteries are blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart to various parts of the body. They do not play a direct role in filariasis. Filariasis is a parasitic infection caused by thread-like filarial worms, typically transmitted through mosquito bites. The worms primarily affect the lymphatic system, not the arteries.

Option B - Vein: Veins are blood vessels that carry deoxygenated blood back to the heart. Similar to arteries, veins do not have a direct role in filariasis. The infection mainly targets the lymphatic system, leading to the characteristic swelling of body parts due to impaired lymph flow.

Option D - DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): DVT is a condition where a blood clot forms in a deep vein, usually in the legs. While DVT involves veins, it is unrelated to filariasis. DVT results from the formation of blood clots within veins, often due to factors like prolonged immobility, certain medical conditions, or genetic predisposition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient undergoes a routine thyroid examination, during which a palpable thyroid nodule is discovered. Fine-needle aspiration cytology confirms the presence of papillary thyroid cancer. All of the following statements are true regarding papillary thyroid cancer Except:

choices.text: It often presents with cervical lymph node metastases.
It is the most common type of thyroid cancer.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It arises from parafollicular C-cells:

  • Papillary thyroid cancer arises from follicular cells of the thyroid gland, not from parafollicular C-cells. Parafollicular C-cells, also known as parathyroid cells or clear cells, are responsible for producing calcitonin, a hormone that regulates calcium levels in the body.
