Medullary thyroid cancer, a different type of thyroid cancer, arises from parafollicular C-cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It often presents with cervical lymph node metastases: Papillary thyroid cancer commonly spreads to nearby lymph nodes in the neck. This is a characteristic feature of this type of thyroid cancer.

Option B - It is the most common type of thyroid cancer: Papillary thyroid cancer is indeed the most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for approximately 70-80% of all cases.

Option D - It is TSH dependent: Papillary thyroid cancer is generally considered to be TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) dependent. TSH, which is produced by the pituitary gland, stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones. Elevated TSH levels can contribute to the growth and function of papillary thyroid cancer cells. This is why TSH suppression therapy (using medications to lower TSH levels) is often part of the treatment plan for papillary thyroid cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with following skin lesions characterized by red and scaly patches. The patient also complains of a painful and swollen finger joint. On examination, the finger joint appears inflamed and tender to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs in some individuals with psoriasis, a skin condition characterized by red and scaly patches. It often involves joint inflammation, especially in the DIP. The patient's symptoms of red and scaly skin lesions along with painful and swollen finger joints are indicative of psoriatic arthritis. This condition can cause joint pain, stiffness, and swelling, and it is commonly associated with skin manifestations like psoriasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pseudo gout: Pseudo gout is a type of arthritis caused by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joints. It can also lead to joint inflammation and pain, but it typically doesn't have an association with skin lesions like psoriasis. The symptoms described in the case, including the skin lesions, make psoriatic arthritis a more likely diagnosis.

Option C - Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in the joints. It is more common in older individuals and typically presents with joint pain and stiffness. However, it does not usually involve the red and scaly skin lesions mentioned in the case.

Option D - Reactive arthritis: Reactive arthritis, also known as Reiter's syndrome, is an inflammatory condition that typically develops as a response to an infection in another part of the body. It often involves joint inflammation, especially in the lower limbs, and can be associated with skin lesions. However, the case description of red and scaly patches on the skin, along with finger joint DIP involvement, is more suggestive of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -Rape victim:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of rape victims

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fetus malformation: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done beyond 24 weeks if the fetus is found to have severe malformations or abnormalities that are incompatible with life or would result in significant physical or mental challenges for the child.

Option B - Minors: Minors generally require parental or guardian consent for medical procedures, including abortion. The laws regarding abortion for minors can vary by country and jurisdiction, but typically there are provisions for involving parents or guardians in the decision-making process.

Option C - Contraception failure: Medical termination of pregnancy is not typically allowed solely due to contraception failure. However, if the failure of contraception leads to unwanted pregnancy and the woman's health or life is at risk, abortion might be considered based on medical assessment.

questions.text: Following the death of a 40-year-old male patient, his relatives mention that he had a tattoo on his body. However, upon autopsy, no tattoo is observed on the skin. What is the best location to check for the presence of the tattoo?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymph node

  • Lymph nodes are part of the lymphatic system, which is involved in immune response and filtering lymph fluid. It's possible that tattoo pigment particles could be transported to nearby lymph nodes.
  • Therefore, if a tattoo was missing from the skin's surface but was present at some point, examining the regional lymph nodes might reveal the presence of tattoo pigment particles that have been transported through the lymphatic system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Spleen: The spleen is an organ involved in filtering blood and maintaining immune functions. Tattoos are not typically found within the spleen, so this option is not relevant to locating a missing tattoo.

Option B - Artery: Arteries are blood vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart. Tattoos are not typically located within arteries, as they are usually placed in the skin's dermal layer. Checking an artery would not be a logical step to locate a missing tattoo.

Option D - Liver: The liver is a vital organ involved in various metabolic processes. Tattoos are not typically located within the liver. The liver's function is not related to the presence or absence of tattoos, so checking the liver would not help locate a missing tattoo.

questions.text: During a forensic autopsy, a gunshot victim is examined, and the doctor observes that the firearm injury has a stellate shape. What will be the range of gunshot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Contact shot

  • A contact shot occurs when the muzzle of the firearm is in direct contact with the victim's skin at the time of firing. This results in the deposition of soot, unburned powder particles, and even possible charring around the entrance wound. The gases and particles from the gunpowder can cause the surrounding skin to exhibit a stellate or star-shaped pattern due to the pressure and heat.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Close shot: A close shot refers to a gunshot that is fired from a relatively short distance, usually within a few inches to a few feet. In a close shot, there might be stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound, but the injury would not typically exhibit a stellate (star-shaped) appearance.

Option C - Near shot: A near shot, also known as a close intermediate shot, refers to a gunshot fired from a short distance but not in direct contact with the skin. The range is usually a few inches to a few feet. This might result in stippling or powder tattooing around the entrance wound due to the impact of unburned gunpowder particles on the skin. However, it is less likely to produce a stellate wound pattern as seen in contact shots.

Option D - Distant shot: A distant shot is fired from a considerable distance, and the effects on the body are determined by the range of fire. At a greater distance, the bullet's energy dissipates, and there may be no stippling or soot deposition around the entrance wound. The wound tends to be cleaner and smaller compared to closer shots. A stellate wound pattern is unlikely to be present in a distant shot.

questions.text: In a forensic investigation, the police recover a beheaded skull bone and receive a photograph of a missing person from their relatives. These two samples can be analyzed using which technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Superimposition

  • Superimposition is a technique where an image, such as a photograph of a missing person's face, is overlaid onto another image, like a skull, to see if the facial features match. This technique can help determine if the skull belongs to the missing person based on the alignment of key features. It's a common method used in forensic investigations involving skeletal remains and photographs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fingerprint: Fingerprint analysis is primarily used for identifying individuals based on unique patterns of ridges and valleys on their fingertips. It's not directly applicable in this scenario since it wouldn't help analyze a beheaded skull bone or a photograph of a missing person.

Option B - DNA Fingerprint: DNA fingerprinting, also known as DNA profiling, involves analyzing specific regions of an individual's DNA to identify unique genetic patterns. While it can be useful in identifying individuals from biological samples, such as blood or tissue, it's not directly applicable to analyzing a beheaded skull bone or a photograph.

Option D - Cheiloscopy: Cheiloscopy involves the study of lip prints, which can be used for identification purposes. However, it's not likely to be applicable in this scenario involving a beheaded skull bone and a photograph of a missing person.

questions.text: A doctor was summoned as a public witness to appear and record his evidence in court. What is correct about this witness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Expert witness

  • This is the correct answer. An expert witness is someone who possesses specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise in a particular field that is relevant to the case. In the given scenario, a doctor is summoned as a witness. If the doctor's testimony is related to their medical expertise and is meant to provide insight and explanation to the court on medical matters, then they would be considered an expert witness

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral evidence: Oral evidence refers to the testimony or statements provided by witnesses verbally in court. This option does not accurately describe the scenario in which a doctor is summoned as a witness. The scenario mentioned doesn't specifically emphasize the mode of evidence (oral or written) but focuses on the role of the witness.

Option B - Common witness: There is no standard term called "common witness." Witnesses can be categorized based on various factors, but this terminology isn't commonly used. The scenario doesn't provide enough information to suggest that the doctor in question is a "common witness."

Option D - Hostile witness: A hostile witness is a term used to describe a witness who is uncooperative or openly antagonistic towards the party that called them to testify. This option is not applicable to the scenario provided, where a doctor is summoned as a public witness to record evidence in court.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presenting for a dental examination, what is the expected number of permanent and temporary teeth?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 20 & 4 

  • By the age of 10, a child would typically have 20 permanent teeth and 4 remaining primary (temporary) molars.
  • Permanent teeth include incisors, canines, premolars, and molars. The primary molars are usually replaced by permanent premolars.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 24 & 4: This option is incorrect. By the age of 10, a child would typically have 20 permanent teeth and 4 remaining primary (temporary) molars

Option C - 16 & 8: This option is incorrect. 16 permanent teeth and 8 primary teeth would not be the expected number for a 10-year-old child. The total count is higher than it should be.

Option D - 12 & 12: This option is incorrect. At the age of 10, a child would not have only 12 primary teeth (temporary teeth) and 12 permanent teeth. The total count of 20 teeth would be mostly permanent by this age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient was found unconscious in his backyard, the leaves of a plant similar to the one shown below were found scattered around him. He is now presenting with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irregular heart rate. Identify the plant given below likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Yellow Oleander (Thevetia peruviana)

  • Yellow oleander contains toxic cardiac glycosides, which can affect the heart's rhythm and function. Ingestion of any part of the plant can lead to symptoms like nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate, and even death. The symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate) match those associated with yellow oleander poisoning.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ricinus communis (Castor Bean Plant): Ricinus communis contains the deadly toxin ricin. While its seeds are highly toxic, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and potentially fatal organ damage, the symptoms described in the case (irregular heart rate) don't typically align with ricin poisoning. Ricin primarily affects the gastrointestinal system and other organs.

Option C - Datura: Datura contains tropane alkaloids that can lead to symptoms like hallucinations, delirium, dry mouth, blurred vision, and an increased heart rate. While some symptoms could match (such as irregular heart rate), the prominent gastrointestinal symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea) are not characteristic of Datura poisoning.

Option D - Papaver somniferum (Opium Poppy): While opium poppy can produce opiates like morphine and codeine, the symptoms associated with its ingestion include respiratory depression, sedation, pinpoint pupils, and potential overdose symptoms. The symptoms described in the case (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, irregular heart rate) do not align well with opium poppy poisoning.

questions.text: The dead body of a 30-year-old male drowning victim was brought in for autopsy. Upon examination, multiple cuts were observed on the victim's arm. What finding is likely to be seen in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Defense wound

  • When a person is attacked or struggling to defend themselves against an assailant, they might sustain what are known as defense wounds. These wounds typically occur on the flexor surface of the forearm, as individuals instinctively raise their arms to protect their face and body during an attack. The cuts on the victim's arm in this scenario are consistent with defense wounds, suggesting that the victim was trying to shield themselves from harm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Self-inflicted injury: Self-inflicted injuries are wounds that a person intentionally inflicts upon themselves. These injuries might result from self-harm or suicide attempts. However, in the given scenario, the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm does not necessarily suggest self-inflicted injury, as the location and pattern of the cuts seem more indicative of defensive actions rather than self-infliction.

Option C - Accidental cut wound from falling: An accidental cut wound from falling might result from an individual accidentally coming into contact with a sharp object while falling. However, this scenario is less likely in this case because the presence of multiple cuts on the flexor surface of the arm is not consistent with typical patterns of injuries sustained during a fall.

Option D - Washer-women hands: "Washer-women hands" is a term used to describe the appearance of the fingers and hands after prolonged exposure to water, like during laundry work. This option is not relevant to the scenario described, as it does not explain the presence of multiple cuts on the victim's arm or the context of the drowning incident.

questions.text: A 42 year old patient, a case of road traffic accident presented with EDH due to involvement of Middle Meningeal Artery. Where will the impact of collision be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pterion

  • The impact of the collision resulting in an epidural hematoma (EDH) due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery is likely to occur at the pterion. The pterion is a small, delicate area on the side of the skull where four bones come together: the frontal bone, the parietal bone, the temporal bone, and the sphenoid bone. This area is particularly vulnerable to traumatic injury due to its thin bone structure and the presence of the Middle Meningeal Artery, which runs just beneath the skull in this region. Trauma to the pterion can lead to a rupture of the Middle Meningeal Artery, causing bleeding between the dura mater and the skull, resulting in an epidural hematoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is the outermost point of the lower jawbone. While trauma to this area can cause facial injuries, it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery.

Option C - Lambdoid suture: The lambdoid suture is the joint between the occipital bone (back of the skull) and the parietal bones. Trauma to this area can result in injuries to the posterior part of the skull, but it is not typically associated with epidural hematomas involving the Middle Meningeal Artery.

Option D - Nasion: The nasion is the intersection point between the frontal bone and the two nasal bones. Trauma to this area can lead to facial injuries, but it is not directly associated with the development of an epidural hematoma due to involvement of the Middle Meningeal Artery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism goes to a liquor store and purchases two bottles of liquor. Approximately one hour later, after consuming alcohol, he presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal discomfort, acute confusion, vision loss, and an unsteady gait. What is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ethyl alcohol

  • The patient's presentation with abdominal discomfort, acute confusion, vision loss, and an unsteady gait after consuming alcohol are suggestive of methanol poisoning.
  • Ethyl alcohol (ethanol) is used as an antidote for methanol poisoning because it competes with methanol for the same enzyme, alcohol dehydrogenase, thereby preventing the formation of toxic metabolites (formaldehyde and formic acid) from methanol.
  • This treatment helps to reduce the toxic effects and allows time for methanol to be excreted unchanged by the kidneys.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: When does the talus become ossified during intrauterine life?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 7 months 

  • Around 7 months of intrauterine life, the ossification process begins in the talus. Ossification centers develop in various bones during fetal development, and the talus is no exception. The talus bone starts to calcify and transform from cartilage to bone tissue around this time.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3 months: At 3 months of intrauterine life, the talus is in its cartilaginous form and has not yet undergone ossification. Ossification refers to the process by which cartilage is replaced by bone tissue.

Option C - 9 months: By 9 months of intrauterine life, most of the major bones have undergone substantial ossification, including the talus. At this stage, the talus is well on its way to becoming a fully ossified bone.

Option D - 2 months: At 2 months of intrauterine life, the talus is still in its early stages of development, and the process of ossification has not yet commenced. The fetal skeletal system is primarily composed of cartilage during this period.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the emergency department after consuming a significant quantity of iron tablets at home. The child is presenting with severe abdominal pain, profuse gastrointestinal bleeding episodes, and lethargy. What is the preferred treatment for this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Deferoxamine Mesylate

  • This is the correct answer. Deferoxamine Mesylate is a chelating agent specifically used to treat iron poisoning. It forms a complex with iron, which is then excreted through the urine. Iron poisoning can lead to severe complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding and organ damage, so prompt and effective treatment with Deferoxamine Mesylate is essential.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pencillamine: Penicillamine is a chelating agent primarily used to treat Wilson's disease and rheumatoid arthritis. It is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning.

Option B - BAL (British Anti-Lewisite or Dimercaprol): BAL is a chelating agent used to treat heavy metal poisoning, such as lead and arsenic poisoning. It is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning.

Option C - Activated charcoal: Activated charcoal is used to absorb certain toxins in the gastrointestinal tract. However, in the case of iron poisoning, it is not effective because iron tablets have already been absorbed and are causing systemic effects.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient after an injury presented with a deformity as shown in the image. Which nerve will be damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radial Nerve

  • In the given scenario, the image displaying wrist drop and a fracture of the shaft of the humerus is indicative of damage to the radial nerve

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ulnar Nerve: The ulnar nerve mainly innervates forearm and hand muscles for wrist flexion and finger abduction. It's not typically involved in wrist drop.

Option C - Median Nerve: The median nerve innervates specific forearm muscles and the hand's anterior compartment but isn't heavily involved in wrist extension, the main problem in the image.

Option D - Musculocutaneous Nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve mainly innervates the anterior arm muscles, like the biceps brachii, aiding in elbow flexion, not wrist extension.

questions.text: A person who had a road traffic accident presented to ER with injury to bulbar urethra. What can be the location of collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anterior abdominal wall

  • The correct answer. The bulbar urethra is a part of the male urethra located just before the penile urethra. An injury to the bulbar urethra can lead to a urethral rupture, allowing urine to leak into the surrounding tissues. In the case of bulbar urethral rupture, the urine extravasates to
    • Superficial perineal pouch
    • Scrotum
    • Penile region
    • Anterior abdominal wall

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inguinal pouch: The inguinal pouch is not a typical location for urine collection. It is an area in the groin region, and urine collection there wouldn't be directly related to a bulbar urethral injury.

Option B - Peritoneal cavity: The peritoneal cavity is the abdominal cavity where various organs are located. It is not a common location for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. Leakage of urine into the peritoneal cavity could result in a condition known as urinoma, but this is not the primary location of urine collection in cases of bulbar urethral injury.

Option C - Ischiorectal fossa: The ischiorectal fossa is situated in the pelvic region, but it is not a usual site for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. This fossa contains fat and connective tissue and is not directly connected to the urinary system.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male was climbing the stair, suddenly he fell & an iron nail hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is having a hard time shrugging his shoulders and he is having difficulty turning his head. This might be due to an injury to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spinal accessory Nerve :

  • The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. In this scenario, the patient's difficulty in shrugging his shoulders and turning his head suggests an issue with the spinal accessory nerve, which controls these muscles. The injury caused by the nail hitting his neck could have damaged or impinged the spinal accessory nerve, leading to these symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Deltoid Muscle: The symptoms described are not directly related to the function of the deltoid muscle, which is responsible for shoulder abduction.

Option C - Sternocleidomastoid Muscle: Sternocleidomastoid muscle is involved in head and neck movements such as rotation and tilting, it is not responsible for shoulder shrugging.

Option D - Long Thoracic Nerve: Damage to the long thoracic nerve can lead to scapular "winging," where the scapula protrudes outward from the back due to weakened serratus anterior muscle.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female, who works as a maid complained of knee pain and swelling. Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - B (Prepatellar bursa)

  • The correct answer is option b (Prepatellar bursa), as housemaid's knee involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa due to repeated kneeling or trauma to the front of the knee.Housemaid's knee, also known as prepatellar bursitis, involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa. The prepatellar bursa is located just in front of the patella (kneecap) and can become inflamed due to repetitive kneeling or trauma to the area. This condition is often seen in individuals who perform activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as housemaids or carpet layers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A (Suprapatellar bursa): The suprapatellar bursa is located above the patella (kneecap) and helps reduce friction between the femur (thigh bone) and the quadriceps tendon. This bursa is not commonly associated with housemaid's knee.

Option C - C (Infrapatellar bursa): The infrapatellar bursa is located below the patella, between the patellar ligament and the tibia (shin bone). It helps reduce friction during knee movements. Inflammation of this bursa is known as "clergyman's knee" or "Clergyman's bursitis," which is caused by excessive kneeling and friction.

Option D - D (Pes anserine bursa): The pes anserine bursa is located on the inner side of the knee, just below the joint. It is situated between the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles and the underlying tibia. Inflammation of this bursa can lead to pes anserine bursitis, which typically presents as pain and tenderness on the inner side of the knee. This condition is not directly related to housemaid's knee.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who had the extraction of her 3rd molar tooth reported loss of sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and floor of the mouth. Which nerve is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lingual Nerve:

  • The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and the floor of the mouth. Damage to the lingual nerve during the extraction of the 3rd molar tooth (also known as a wisdom tooth) can result in loss of sensation in these areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glossopharyngeal Nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) conveys taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue, not the anterior 2/3rd or floor of the mouth.

Option C - Spinal Accessory Nerve: The spinal accessory nerve (XI) mainly controls head and shoulder movements. It's unrelated to tongue or mouth floor sensation.

Option D - Chorda Tympani Nerve: The chorda tympani nerve conveys taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue and regulates salivary glands. Not connected to mouth floor sensation. Damage usually from middle ear surgery, not molar extraction.

questions.text: Which bone is most likely to be fractured in an injury to the anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Scaphoid

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression located on the radial aspect of the dorsum (back) of the hand. It is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles. Fractures within the anatomical snuff box are commonly associated with falls onto an outstretched hand, particularly with the wrist extended. The most fractured bone in this region is the scaphoid bone, also known as the navicular bone.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lunar (lunate) bone: The lunate bone, found in the wrist joint, rarely fractures in injuries to the anatomical snuff box and isn't usually part of its formation.

Option C - Cuboid bone: The cuboid bone is one of the tarsal bones located in the foot. It is not related to the anatomical snuff box or the wrist region.

Option D - Trapezius: The trapezius is a large muscle located in the upper back and neck area. It is not a bone and is not related to the anatomical snuff box or wrist injuries.

questions.text: A farmer sprayed a chemical in the pool which causes inhibition of complex-III of the electron transport chain. Identify the inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Antimycin:

  • Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome b-c1 complex) of the electron transport chain. It interrupts the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, thereby inhibiting the flow of electrons through this complex.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I of the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone in the mitochondrial respiratory chain.

Option B - TTFA: TTFA(Thenoyltrifluoroacetone is an inhibitor of complex II of the electron transport chain. 

Option C - Cyanide: Cyanide is an inhibitor of complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons to oxygen, disrupting the final step of electron transport and therefore blocking the production of ATP.

questions.text: The given finding is associated with ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21, commonly known as Down syndrome, results from an extra copy of chromosome 21. People with Down syndrome often have distinct facial features, intellectual disabilities, and certain medical problems. Approximately half of individuals with Down syndrome have a single transverse palmar crease, making this the correct answer. The simian crease is relatively common in Down syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trisomy 13: Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, results from an extra chromosome 13, leading to severe developmental issues and congenital abnormalities. While hand anomalies are common, a simian crease isn't typically present.

Option C - Klinefelter's syndrome: Klinefelter's syndrome in males with an extra X chromosome (XXY) leads to male hypogonadism and physical differences, but it's not usually linked to a simian crease.

Option D - Trisomy 18: Trisomy 18, or Edwards syndrome, stems from an extra chromosome 18, leading to severe developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and congenital anomalies. While hand abnormalities may occur, a simian crease isn't a defining trait.

questions.text: In a 2-year-old child with a sudden onset of noisy breathing, which type of stridor is most likely to be represented by the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Inspiratory:

Explanation:

  • In the context of a 2-year-old child with sudden onset noisy breathing and an omega-shaped epiglottis (which is a common presentation of laryngomalacia), inspiratory stridor is the most likely option.
  • Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition characterized by the softening of the tissues of the larynx above the vocal cords. It is the most common cause of stridor in infants.
  • The epiglottis in laryngomalacia often has an elongated, curled appearance, resembling the Greek letter omega (Ω), which can be observed during laryngoscopy.
  • This condition typically presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens with feeding, crying, or lying supine, and usually improves by the age of 18 to 24 months as the cartilage stiffens and the airway grows.

(Option B) Expiratory: Expiratory stridor occurs when there is narrowing or obstruction of the airway during exhalation. This is less likely to be the case in a child with an omega-shaped epiglottis, as the obstruction is primarily during inspiration due to the swollen epiglottis.

(Option C) Biphasic: Biphasic stridor involves noisy breathing during both inspiration and expiration. This is less likely in the given scenario, as the omega-shaped epiglottis suggests a specific structural issue related to inspiration, rather than both phases of breathing.

(Option D) None of these: Given the information provided about the sudden onset of noisy breathing and the specific appearance of the epiglottis, inspiratory stridor is the most suitable choice among the options.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level shown by the blue line in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - L4-L5 

  • If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - L2-L3: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

Option C - L5-S1: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

Option D - L3-L4: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Cholera is known to cause diarrhea through its interaction with specific receptors in the human body. Which of the following is known to make it easier for cholera toxin to enter the body through the intestinal mucosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - GM1 ganglioside:

  • Cholera toxin is produced by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae and is responsible for causing the characteristic symptoms of cholera, including severe diarrhea. Cholera toxin enters the body through the intestinal mucosa and interacts with specific receptors on the surface of intestinal cells.
  • The receptor that facilitates the entry of cholera toxin into the body is the GM1 ganglioside receptor. GM1 ganglioside is a glycosphingolipid, a type of molecule found in the lipid bilayer of cell membranes. Cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside on the surface of intestinal cells, which triggers the toxin to be internalized into the cell through endocytosis. Once inside the cell, the toxin can exert its effects, leading to the disruption of ion transport and fluid balance, ultimately causing severe diarrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - GLUT1 (Glucose Transporter 1): GLUT1 is a protein responsible for transporting glucose across cell membranes. It is not directly involved in the interaction between cholera toxin and intestinal cells.

Option B - GM2 ganglioside: While GM2 ganglioside is a type of glycosphingolipid, it is not the receptor specifically associated with cholera toxin binding and entry into intestinal cells.

Option C - Cephalin: Cephalin is a type of phospholipid and is not known to be directly involved in the interaction between cholera toxin and intestinal cells.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman is being evaluated for daytime sleepiness and memory loss which have been present for the past 1 year. Her BMI is 43, her BP is 170/98 mmHg. In an awake state, ABG shows pO2 70 mmHg, pCO2 53 mmHg, HCO3 33 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS):

  • This disorder occurs in severely obese individuals who experience hypoventilation (inadequate breathing) during sleep and wakefulness. The elevated BMI, daytime sleepiness, and memory loss are consistent with OHS. The elevated pCO2 (53 mmHg) and elevated HCO3 (33 mmol/L) on the ABG indicate chronic respiratory acidosis and compensation, which is a characteristic feature of OHS. The high blood pressure (BP) also supports this diagnosis as OHS is associated with increased cardiovascular risks.
  • In summary given the patient's severe obesity, daytime sleepiness, memory loss, high BMI, elevated BP, and the ABG results showing chronic respiratory acidosis, the most likely diagnosis is Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central Sleep Apnea (CSA): CSA involves a dysfunction in the central nervous system's control of breathing during sleep, leading to temporary cessation of breathing. While CSA can cause daytime sleepiness, the ABG values (elevated pCO2 and HCO3) suggest a respiratory-related issue rather than a primary central nervous system problem.

Option C - Narcolepsy: Narcolepsy is a neurological disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, often accompanied by sudden muscle weakness (cataplexy), sleep paralysis, and vivid dream-like hallucinations. It doesn't typically involve significant respiratory disturbances as seen in this case.

Option D - Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA): OSA is a condition where the airway becomes partially or completely blocked during sleep, leading to repeated pauses in breathing. While OSA can cause daytime sleepiness and memory issues, the ABG findings of elevated pCO2 and HCO3 are more indicative of a chronic respiratory problem like OHS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with chronic sinusitis and nasal congestion, which anatomical structure is the most likely drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Middle meatus:

  • The middle meatus is the most likely drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis. The bulla ethmoidalis is a rounded bony prominence in the ethmoidal labyrinth (a part of the ethmoid bone) located in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. It is associated with the middle nasal concha. The middle meatus is a space located between the middle and inferior nasal conchae (turbinates), which are bony structures in the nasal cavity that help to create turbulence in the inspired air. The bulla ethmoidalis drains into the middle meatus through the ethmoid infundibulum, which is a narrow passage connecting the bulla to the middle meatus. This drainage pathway is important for proper ventilation and drainage of the frontal and anterior ethmoid sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior meatus: The superior meatus is not the correct drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis. The superior meatus is located above the middle nasal concha and is primarily associated with the posterior ethmoid air cells.

Option C - Inferior meatus: The inferior meatus is not the correct drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis. The inferior meatus is located below the middle nasal concha and is primarily associated with the nasolacrimal duct and the opening of the maxillary sinus.

Option D - Middle concha: The term "middle concha" is not commonly used. Instead, there are the "superior nasal concha" and the "middle nasal concha." The middle nasal concha is located between the superior and inferior nasal conchae and contributes to the formation of the middle meatus. However, the drainage pathway for the bulla ethmoidalis is not directly associated with the middle concha but rather with the middle meatus.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with swelling due to a collection of blood around the eyes after sustaining a head injury. Which structural attachment is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aponeurosis attachment:

  • When a person sustains a head injury, especially around the eyes, blood can collect in the surrounding tissues due to ruptured blood vessels. The blood can accumulate in the subcutaneous space, causing swelling. The structural attachment that can contribute to this condition is the aponeurosis attachment.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Periosteum: The periosteum is a tough connective tissue layer on bone surfaces. It aids in bone health but isn't directly linked to swelling around the eyes from head injuries.

Option C - Cellulitis: Cellulitis, a bacterial skin infection, doesn't typically lead to blood collection and swelling post-head injury.

Option D - None of the above: The correct answer is A. Aponeurosis attachment, as explained above. Therefore, the option "None of the above" is not the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: A infant developed difficulty in breathing. His symptoms improve with crying. In which disease, symptoms get improve with crying?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Choanal atresia:

  • Choanal atresia is a congenital condition where there is a blockage or narrowing of the back of the nasal passage (choanae) that leads from the nasal cavity to the throat. This blockage can make it difficult for an infant to breathe through their nose. Interestingly, infants with choanal atresia often improve their breathing when they cry. When they cry, they open their mouths wider, allowing more air to flow into their lungs through their mouth, bypassing the blocked nasal passages. This temporary improvement in breathing during crying is a characteristic feature of choanal atresia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thinning and inflammation of the nasal mucosa, leading to symptoms like nasal crusting, foul odor, and nasal congestion. Crying is unlikely to significantly improve symptoms in atrophic rhinitis.

Option B - Acute rhinosinusitis: Acute rhinosinusitis is an inflammation of the nasal and sinus passages, often caused by infections. While crying might lead to temporary relief of symptoms due to increased nasal secretions, it's not a defining characteristic of this condition.

Option C - Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is an allergic reaction that leads to symptoms like sneezing, itching, runny or stuffy nose. Crying might temporarily relieve some symptoms, but it's not a specific feature of allergic rhinitis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to feeding difficulties, vomiting, and failure to thrive. The child's history reveals that the infant wasborn full-term and had a normal birth weight. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced, and the liver is palpable below the costal margin. Oil drop Cataracts are also noted on eye examination. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of galactose in the blood and urine. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - GALT (Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase) deficiency:

  • GALT deficiency, also known as galactosemia, is a genetic disorder that impairs the ability to metabolize galactose properly. Galactose is a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
  • In individuals with GALT deficiency, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates, leading to various symptoms, including feeding difficulties, vomiting, failure to thrive, jaundice, and liver enlargement.
  • Cataracts are also a characteristic feature of galactosemia. This condition requires the removal of galactose from the diet to prevent complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency: G6PD deficiency is a genetic disorder that leads to a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, which is important for protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

Option C - ALDH (Aldehyde dehydrogenase) deficiency: ALDH deficiency is associated with a condition called alcohol-induced flushing, where individuals who carry certain genetic variants of the aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme experience facial flushing and other symptoms when they consume alcohol.

Option D - PKU (Phenylalanine hydroxylase) deficiency: PKU is a genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a swelling below the ear and complains of pain in the lobule of the ear. The patient also reports difficulty in completely closing the left eye and experiences trouble while eating food. What nerve is most likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Facial nerve

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) controls facial expressions, including eye closure and smiling. Damage to it can cause weakness or paralysis in these muscles. Additionally, it regulates muscles for eating and swallowing, which aligns with the patient's eating difficulties..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Greater Auricular nerve: Damage to this nerve might result in altered sensation around the ear, but it wouldn't explain the symptoms mentioned in the case.

Option B - Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve provides sensation to the external ear and part of the scalp. However, it doesn't control facial movement, eye closure, or eating functions.

Option D - Vagus nerve: While damage to the vagus nerve might cause some difficulties in swallowing and speech, it would not explain the specific symptoms of facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, or earlobe pain described in the case.

questions.text: A 60 year old man present with sudden onset of right sided hemiparesis for last 3 hours. BP is 200/100 mmHg. NCCT Head showed brain bleed and right hemiparesis. All of the following are to be done for management, Except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Thrombolysis:

  • Thrombolysis, also known as clot-busting therapy, involves administering medications to dissolve blood clots. It is typically used in the treatment of ischemic strokes (caused by a blood clot blocking a blood vessel in the brain). However, in this case, the patient's presentation and brain imaging findings suggest a hemorrhagic stroke, which is characterized by bleeding into the brain tissue. Administering thrombolytic therapy in a hemorrhagic stroke could exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition, which is why thrombolysis is contraindicated in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - BP Control: High blood pressure (hypertension) is a risk factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes. In the context of a hemorrhagic stroke, controlling blood pressure is crucial to prevent further bleeding and manage the patient's overall condition. So, BP control is an essential part of the management.

Option C - Edema Management: Brain edema (swelling) can occur following a stroke, and it can lead to increased intracranial pressure, potentially causing further damage. Edema management might involve measures such as elevating the head of the bed, using osmotic agents, and closely monitoring the patient's neurological status. This is an important aspect of stroke management.

Option D - Elective Hyperventilation: Elective hyperventilation, which involves intentionally increasing breathing rate, can lead to a decrease in carbon dioxide levels in the blood. This can lead to constriction of blood vessels in the brain (vasoconstriction) and reduction of cerebral blood flow. While it was previously used in the management of elevated intracranial pressure, it is generally not recommended due to the risk of worsening cerebral ischemia. Instead, other methods for intracranial pressure control are preferred.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient weighing 80 kilograms has been diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke and is recommended for thrombolysis with alteplase. What should the initial stat dose in milligrams be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 8

  • Streptokinase is always given in the form of an infusion over 1 hour but alteplase, some part of it can be given as a bolus shot and the remaining can be given as infusion. 10% of the total dose need to be given in the form of a bolus.

Calculation of the Total Dose:

  • The standard dose of alteplase for acute ischemic stroke is 0.9 mg per kilogram of body weight, with a maximum total dose of 90 mg.
  • For an 80 kg patient: Total dose=80 kg×0.9 mg/kg=72 mg

Administration of the Dose:

  • Bolus Dose: 10% of the total dose is administered as an initial bolus over 1 minute.
    • Bolus dose=10%×72 mg=7.2 mg
  • Infusion Dose: The remaining 90% of the total dose is administered as an intravenous infusion over 60 minutes.
    • Infusion dose=90%×72 mg=64.8 mg

Since the maximum dose of alteplase is 90 mg, and the calculated dose is 72 mg, the patient will receive the calculated dose of 72 mg. The 10 % of this will be 7.2 and the closest option is 8 so the answer is Option A

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 10

Option C - 12

Option D - 15

questions.text: What investigation is carried out immediately after a child is suspected of having inhaled a foreign body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chest X-ray:

  • After a child inhales or ingests a foreign body, a chest X-ray is often the initial investigation carried out. A chest X-ray can help identify the location and potential presence of a foreign body in the lungs or airways. It provides a quick and non-invasive way to assess the situation and determine the appropriate course of action.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rigid bronchoscopy: Rigid bronchoscopy is a procedure in which a rigid tube is inserted into the airways to visualize and remove foreign bodies or other obstructions. While this is indeed a procedure that may be carried out to remove a foreign body from a child's lung, it is not typically the immediate investigation performed right after a child ingests or inhales a foreign body.

Option C - Direct laryngoscopy: Direct laryngoscopy is a procedure that involves examining the larynx (voice box) and adjacent structures using a laryngoscope. While this procedure might be used to examine the upper airway and larynx, it is not typically the first investigation performed when a foreign body is suspected in the lower airways or lungs.

Option D - Flexible endoscopy: Flexible endoscopy involves using a flexible tube with a camera on the end to visualize internal structures. While this procedure can be used to examine the airways and remove foreign bodies, it might not be the immediate investigation performed right after a child inhales or ingests a foreign body.

questions.text: All of the following will show Hypokalemia Except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - RTA 4 (Renal Tubular Acidosis Type 4):

  • RTA4, also known as hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis or hypoaldosteronism, involves impaired hydrogen and potassium ion secretion in the distal tubules of the kidneys due to decreased aldosterone production or resistance to aldosterone. This leads to both hyperkalemia and acidosis. Therefore, RTA4 does not cause hypokalemia; it's associated with hyperkalemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RTA1 (Renal Tubular Acidosis Type 1): RTA1 is also known as distal renal tubular acidosis. It involves impaired acid secretion by the distal tubules of the kidneys, leading to an inability to excrete hydrogen ions and reabsorb bicarbonate ions effectively. Impaired ammonium chloride excretion as kidney with maintain electroneutrality. Hypokalemia leads to muscle weakness. Metabolic acidosis will impair tubular reabsorption of calcium - Nephrocalcinosis – hypercalciuria

Option B - RTA 2 (Renal Tubular Acidosis Type 2): RTA2, also called proximal renal tubular acidosis, results from impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules of the kidneys. This can lead to hypokalemia. 

Option D - Ureterosigmoidostomy: Ureterosigmoidostomy is a surgical procedure where one or both ureters are connected to the sigmoid colon for urinary diversion after bladder removal or other conditions. In this condition, there's a risk of increased potassium reabsorption in the colon, which can lead to hypokalemia.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the clinic with jaundice and a white, punctate, and scattered opacity in the central lens. The condition is consistent with Oil drop cataract. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Galactosemia:

  • The most likely metabolic disorder responsible for the presentation of oil drop cataract in a newborn infant with jaundice and lens opacities is Galactosemia. Oil drop cataract is a type of cataract characterized by small, white, punctate opacities that resemble oil drops in the lens of the eye. This specific type of cataract is associated with galactosemia, which is an inherited metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to metabolize galactose, a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.
  • In galactosemia, there is a deficiency in one of the enzymes involved in the metabolism of galactose, leading to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, including the lens of the eye. The accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate can result in the formation of the characteristic oil drop opacities seen in the lens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phenylketonuria (PKU): Phenylketonuria is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This leads to the buildup of phenylalanine in the body. However, PKU is not associated with oil drop cataract; instead, it can lead to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and other neurological problems if left untreated.

Option B - Maple syrup urine disease: This is a metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). It can cause neurological symptoms and a characteristic sweet odor to the urine. It is not associated with oil drop cataract.

Option D - Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease is a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. It can cause various neurological and hepatic symptoms. It is not associated with oil drop cataract.

questions.text: Oxaloacetate is produced from which of the following amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Aspartate:

  • Aspartate is the amino acid that contributes to the production of oxaloacetate through transamination reactions in the citric acid cycle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alanine: Alanine can be involved in the glucose-alanine cycle and can be converted into pyruvate, not oxaloacetate.

Option B - Lysine: Lysine is an essential amino acid, and it is not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate.

Option C - Leucine: Leucine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate. It is primarily involved in protein synthesis and can be catabolized to generate acetyl-CoA, which can then enter the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: What is the most common site of ranula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Floor of the mouth:

  • A ranula is a type of mucocele that occurs in the floor of the mouth. It is a cystic swelling that develops due to the obstruction of the salivary gland duct, most commonly the sublingual gland duct. The sublingual gland is located beneath the tongue and its duct can become blocked, leading to the accumulation of saliva and the formation of a cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. Ranulas can vary in size and may cause discomfort or interfere with speech and swallowing.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tonsil: A ranula is not associated with the tonsil. Tonsils are lymphoid tissue masses located at the back of the throat and are part of the immune system, helping to protect against infections. Conditions related to tonsils could include tonsillitis, but not ranulas.

Option C - Uvula: A ranula does not typically occur on the uvula. The uvula is the small, fleshy mass of tissue that hangs down at the back of the throat. Conditions affecting the uvula could include uvulitis (inflammation of the uvula), but ranulas are not associated with this structure.

Option D - Cingula: The term "cingula" might be a bit confusing in this context. The cingulum is a term used in dentistry to refer to the raised, rounded area on the lingual surface of anterior teeth. It's not related to the location of a ranula.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals is best known for insulin secretion stabilisation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Zinc:

  • Zinc is an essential trace mineral that plays a crucial role in numerous biological processes, including insulin secretion and stabilization. It is involved in the synthesis, storage, and release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells. Zinc also helps in maintaining the structure and stability of insulin molecules. Therefore, of the options provided, zinc is the best-known mineral for insulin secretion stabilization.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cadmium: Cadmium is a toxic heavy metal that can have detrimental effects on health, including disrupting various physiological processes. However, it is not known for its role in insulin secretion stabilization.

Option B - Copper: Copper is an essential trace mineral that plays a role in various bodily functions, including the formation of red blood cells and maintaining connective tissues. While it is involved in several enzymatic reactions, it is not primarily known for its role in insulin secretion stabilization.

Option C - Iron: Iron is vital for oxygen transport in the blood and is a key component of hemoglobin. It is not primarily associated with insulin secretion stabilization.

questions.text: A child is brought with a 2-week history of not feeding well and excessive irritability. History of TB for sister is present and is taking treatment for it. In workup, LP was performed. Which of the following is likely to be found in CSF?

choices.text: Lymphocytosis, low sugar, and high protein
Lymphocytosis, high sugar, and high protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and low protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and high protein

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lymphocytosis, low sugar and high protein:

  • This option is the most likely finding in the CSF of a child with a suspected tuberculous meningitis, which is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The history of TB in the sister raises the suspicion of an infectious etiology.
  • Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals a high leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), usually with a predominance of lymphocytes but sometimes with a predominance of neutrophils in the early stage; a protein content of 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL); and a low glucose concentration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lymphocytosis, high sugar and high protein: While lymphocytosis and high protein levels are expected in a CNS infection, high sugar levels (hyperglycorrhachia) are not typical. Viruses and certain bacteria tend to decrease CSF glucose levels due to increased consumption. Therefore, this option is less likely.

Option C - Neutrophils, low sugar, and low protein: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell associated with bacterial infections. The combination of low sugar and low protein levels is not characteristic of most CNS infections, as infections typically lead to increased protein levels due to the inflammatory response. This pattern is not consistent with the clinical presentation and history provided.

Option D - Neutrophils, low sugar, and high protein: While neutrophils could be present in the CSF in cases of acute bacterial meningitis, the combination of low sugar and high protein levels is not typical. Acute bacterial infections tend to lower CSF glucose levels due to consumption, but they also lead to an increase in protein levels. This option does not match the expected pattern for the given clinical scenario.

questions.text: A child with a mild cold who also has adenoid facies has been identified as having chronic adenoid hypertrophy. Which is the best surgical management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coblator:

  • For a child with chronic adenoid hypertrophy and adenoid facies, the best surgical management option among the given choices is Option A: Coblator. This technique offers precise tissue removal with minimal damage, reduced postoperative pain, and faster recovery

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Microdebrider: A microdebrider is a surgical instrument that uses suction and a rotating blade to remove tissue. It is another option for performing adenoidectomy. While it offers precise removal of tissue, it may generate more postoperative bleeding compared to Coblation. Microdebrider-assisted adenoidectomy can also be effective in treating chronic adenoid hypertrophy.

Option C - Curettage: Curettage involves scraping or scooping out tissue using a curette, a surgical instrument with a spoon-shaped end. While this technique was used in the past, it has largely been replaced by more advanced methods like Coblation and microdebrider due to their advantages in terms of reduced bleeding, decreased postoperative pain, and improved recovery.

Option D - Breathing exercise and symptomatic treatment: This option involves non-surgical management of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. Breathing exercises and symptomatic treatments may help manage the symptoms associated with adenoid hypertrophy, but they do not address the underlying issue of enlarged adenoid tissue. In cases where the adenoids are significantly enlarged and causing persistent symptoms, surgical intervention is often recommended to provide more effective and long-lasting relief.

questions.text: Penicillin was given to the patient and immune hemolytic anemia develops. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type 2

  • Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction, also known as cytotoxic hypersensitivity, involves the activation of the immune system against specific cells or tissues. In this case, penicillin can induce the production of antibodies that bind to the patient's own red blood cells, causing them to be targeted and destroyed by the immune system. This is what happens in immune hemolytic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 1: Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction involves the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils. This leads to immediate allergic reactions, such as hay fever, asthma, and anaphylaxis. It is not associated with immune hemolytic anemia.

Option C - Type 3: Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction occurs when immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in various tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. This is typically seen in diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or certain types of vasculitis. It is not directly associated with immune hemolytic anemia.

Option D - Type 4: Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed-type hypersensitivity involving T cells and macrophages. It's associated with cell-mediated immune responses, such as contact dermatitis or granulomatous inflammation. This type of reaction is not directly related to immune hemolytic anemia caused by penicillin.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with movement disorder and tremors in hand, along with the development of cognitive and emotional problems. Which of the following medical disorders is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Huntington's disease:

  • Huntington's disease is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the HTT gene, leading to the accumulation of abnormal protein in the brain. It presents with movement problems (chorea, which are involuntary, random, and brief movements), cognitive decline, and emotional disturbances such as depression and anxiety. The onset usually occurs in adulthood, typically between the ages of 30 and 50. The mutation involves a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CAG repeats) on the HTT gene.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parkinson's disease: While Parkinson's disease can present with movement disorders and tremors, it typically develops in older individuals (usually after the age of 60). Additionally, cognitive and emotional problems are more characteristic of other conditions like Lewy body dementia, which can be associated with parkinsonism.

Option B - Friedreich's ataxia: Friedreich's ataxia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system, causing progressive damage to the spinal cord and peripheral nerves. It is characterized by problems with coordination, balance, and muscle control. While it can lead to movement problems, cognitive and emotional issues are not prominent features of this disorder.

Option C - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease primarily affects memory, thinking, and behavior. It does not typically present with movement disorders and tremors. Cognitive and emotional problems are central to Alzheimer's, but the movement disorder symptoms described (tremors, chorea) are not characteristic of this disorder.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presenting with non-caseating granulomas and a saddle nose perforation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis):

  • The combination of non-caseating granulomas and saddle nose perforation strongly points towards Wegener's granulomatosis (now often referred to as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis), making option C the most likely diagnosis in this case.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TB (Tuberculosis): While TB can also cause granulomas, the presentation of saddle nose perforation is not typically associated with TB. TB commonly affects the lungs and can cause symptoms like cough, fever, and weight loss.

Option B - Leprosy: Leprosy can cause granulomas as well, but saddle nose perforation is not a common feature of leprosy. Leprosy usually affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, leading to skin lesions and nerve damage.

Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis can cause granulomas as part of its secondary stage manifestations, but saddle nose perforation is not a prominent characteristic of syphilis. Syphilis typically causes a variety of symptoms including skin rash, fever, and mucous membrane lesions.

questions.text: In which organelle is DNA present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mitochondria:

  • DNA is present in the mitochondria, which are double-membraned organelles found in the cells of most eukaryotic organisms. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a small circular molecule separate from the nuclear DNA. It carries genetic information essential for the functioning of mitochondria and plays a crucial role in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

Incorrect Options:
Option B - Lysosome: Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing enzymes responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials and substances. They do not contain DNA; their primary function is related to digestion and waste disposal within the cell.

Option C - Endoplasmic Reticulum: The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is an organelle involved in the synthesis, folding, modification, and transport of proteins and lipids. It does not contain DNA. The ER is composed of membranous structures and is mainly responsible for the manufacturing and transportation of molecules within the cell.

Option D - Cytoplasm: The cytoplasm is the gel-like substance found inside the cell, which includes various organelles and is the site of many cellular processes. While the cytoplasm contains various molecules and structures necessary for cell function, DNA itself is not typically present in the cytoplasm. DNA is primarily found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells, where it houses the genetic information required for cell function and development.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss over the past two weeks. She mentions that she recently traveled to a rural area for a camping trip and drank untreated stream water during her stay. On physical examination, no fever is noted, but mild tenderness is present in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. Stool examination reveals the presence of trophozoites and cysts with characteristic "falling leaf" motility under microscopy. Which organism is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Giardia lamblia

  • Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that commonly causes gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and weight loss. The "falling leaf" motility pattern is a classic finding seen in Giardia infections. This motility pattern is due to the unique flagella arrangement of Giardia trophozoites. The fact that the patient drank untreated stream water during her camping trip makes Giardia infection a likely culprit, as it is transmitted via contaminated water sources.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salmonella typhi: Salmonella typhi is a bacterium that causes typhoid fever. It typically presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, and constipation rather than diarrhea. The symptoms described in the scenario, including frequent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and "falling leaf" motility in the stool, are not characteristic of Salmonella typhi infection.

Option B - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery. While it can lead to diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, the "falling leaf" motility is not a characteristic finding for Entamoeba histolytica. Additionally, there is no mention of bloody diarrhea or the presence of colonic ulcers, which are often associated with this infection.

Option D - Cryptosporidium parvum: Cryptosporidium parvum is another protozoan parasite that causes diarrhea. However, the symptoms of cryptosporidiosis are generally more severe in immunocompromised individuals. The stool examination findings in cryptosporidiosis typically reveal oocysts, which are not described as "falling leaf" motility.

questions.text: Which of the following jvp findings seen in a patient with muffled heart sounds, hypotension and raised JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Absent y descent:

  • Y descent is the drop in JVP during early diastole when the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle. In cardiac tamponade, the elevated pressure in the right atrium due to compression prevents normal descent of the JVP during diastole, leading to an absent y descent. This is the correct finding for the given scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Absent x descent: X descent is the drop in JVP during ventricular systole. It's seen in conditions where the right atrium is not excessively obstructed or compressed. In cardiac tamponade, the x descent can actually be exaggerated, not absent.

Option C - C waves are enlarged: C waves on the JVP waveform represent the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction. Enlarged C waves are often seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation, but they are not specifically associated with the given symptoms of muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and raised JVP.

Option D - A waves are absent: A waves correspond to atrial contraction, which occurs just before the tricuspid valve closes. Absent A waves can be seen in conditions like atrial fibrillation or complete heart block, where the atria are not contracting in a coordinated manner. However, absent A waves would not directly explain the combination of symptoms mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text: Hormone-sensitive lipase is activated by all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Insulin:

  • Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas that plays a crucial role in glucose metabolism. It promotes glucose uptake into cells and storage as glycogen in the liver and muscle tissues.
  • However, insulin inhibits the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. When insulin levels are high (e.g., after a meal), lipolysis (breakdown of fats) is suppressed, and the body primarily uses glucose as an energy source.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glucagon:It also stimulates the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase, which leads to the breakdown of stored triglycerides (lipids/fats) into fatty acids in adipose tissue.

Option B - Epinephrine: It activates hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue, causing the breakdown of triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol.

Option C - ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone): While cortisol plays a role in metabolism, it does not directly activate hormone-sensitive lipase. Instead, cortisol can indirectly influence lipid metabolism by affecting other regulatory pathways.

questions.text: 65-year-old man is brought to the hospital with complaints of suddenly not making any sense while speaking using non-sensical grammar though he can speak quickly. He could communicate effectively prior to this. Which of the following defect is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fluent aphasia:

  • Fluent aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent and rapid speech, but the speech often lacks meaningful content. People with fluent aphasia produce long and grammatically complex sentences that might be devoid of actual meaning or might include neologisms (made-up words). They typically have difficulty understanding language and may not realize that their speech is nonsensical.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Motor aphasia: Motor aphasia, also known as Broca's aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in producing speech, with limited vocabulary, slow speech, and impaired grammar. People with motor aphasia struggle to form coherent sentences and might experience frustration due to their communication difficulties.

Option B - Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by word-finding difficulties. People with this type of aphasia have trouble recalling specific words, which leads to pauses and substitutions in their speech. However, their grammar and fluency are relatively intact.

Option D - Conduction aphasia: Conduction aphasia is characterized by difficulty in repeating words and phrases, even though comprehension and spontaneous speech might be relatively intact. People with conduction aphasia have trouble bridging the gap between understanding and speaking, leading to errors in repeating what they have just heard.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with a history of rheumatic heart disease underwent prosthetic valve replacement surgery 6 months ago. He presents to the cardiology clinic with complaints of fever, fatigue, and worsening shortness of breath over the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur and splinter hemorrhages on the nail beds. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely causative organism responsible for this patient's infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcus epidermidis

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis a coagulase-negative staphylococci is a common cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis, especially within the first year after surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptococcus viridans: This is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, not prosthetic valve endocarditis. Streptococcus viridans is a part of the normal flora of the mouth and throat and can cause endocarditis after dental procedures or in people with poor oral hygiene.

Option C - Enterococcus faecalis: This bacterium is a common cause of healthcare-associated infections, including urinary tract infections, wound infections, and, less commonly, endocarditis. While it can cause endocarditis, it is not the most likely cause in this patient who has a prosthetic heart valve.

Option D - Staphylococcus saprophyticus: Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a coagulase-negative staphylococci associated with urinary tract infections commonly.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presenting with autophony, bilateral limb weakness and normal tympanic membrane that move with respiration. What is the probable cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Weight Loss:

  • The symptoms described, particularly autophony (the sensation of hearing one's own voice loudly), a normal tympanic membrane that moves with respiration (indicating patulous Eustachian tube), and bilateral limb weakness, are indicative of significant weight loss.
  • Weight loss can lead to decreased fatty tissue around the Eustachian tube, causing it to remain open (patulous Eustachian tube).
  • This condition causes the tympanic membrane to move with respiration and results in autophony.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meningioma: Meningiomas are usually slow-growing tumors that originate from the meninges, the protective layers covering the brain and spinal cord. They can cause various neurological symptoms depending on their location. While they might lead to symptoms like headache, seizures, or focal neurological deficits, they are less likely to cause the combination of symptoms described in the question, such as autophony (hearing one's own voice abnormally loud), bilateral limb weakness, and normal tympanic membrane movement with respiration.

Option B - Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system, causing a wide range of neurological symptoms. These can include muscle weakness, vision problems, coordination difficulties, and sensory abnormalities. While MS can cause limb weakness, it is less likely to directly lead to symptoms like autophony or affect the movement of the tympanic membrane.

Option D - Wegener’s Granulomatosis: Also known as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), Wegener’s granulomatosis is a rare autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the respiratory tract and kidneys. While it can cause a range of symptoms including sinus problems, lung issues, and kidney problems, it is less likely to cause the specific combination of symptoms described in the question.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - δ Amino-Levulinic Acid synthase (ALA Synthase):

  • This enzyme catalyzes the formation of ALA from glycine and succinyl-CoA. It is the rate-limiting enzyme of the heme synthesis pathway. Its activity is tightly regulated by feedback inhibition by heme itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HMB synthase (5-Aminolevulinic Acid Synthase): This enzyme catalyzes the formation of δ-Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) from succinyl-CoA and glycine. It is not the rate-limiting enzyme but is the first committed step in heme synthesis.

Option B - δ Amino-Levulinic Acid dehydratase (Porphobilinogen synthase): This enzyme catalyzes the condensation of two molecules of ALA to form porphobilinogen. It is not the rate-limiting enzyme either.

Option D – Ferrochelatase: This enzyme catalyzes the final step of heme synthesis, inserting an iron ion into the protoporphyrin ring to form heme. It is not the rate-limiting enzyme but is responsible for the incorporation of iron into the heme molecule.
